webTitle: Barak 'agrees Jerusalem compromise'

fields.headline: Barak 'agrees Jerusalem compromise'
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has accepted a US bridging proposal that would extend limited Palestinian sovereignty  to parts of east Jerusalem, a cabinet minister who is not part of the negotiating team said today, although a negotiator on Barak's team at  Camp David has denied it.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has accepted a US bridging proposal that would extend limited Palestinian sovereignty to parts of east Jerusalem, a cabinet minister who is not part of the negotiating team said today, although a negotiator on Barak's team at Camp David has denied it.

Diaspora affairs minister Michael Melchior, who was in the United States last week at Barak's request as part of Israel's publicity team, would not say how he knew Barak had accepted the US bridging proposal.

"We can accept, under the framework of Israeli sovereignty over all Jerusalem...a certain extended administrative autonomy solution for some of the Muslim quarters outside the Old City, and only outside the Old City," he said.

Eldad Yaniv, an adviser to Barak who is part of the negotiating team near Washington, denied that Barak had accepted any proposal, and said he was waiting for the Palestinians to react before he made his position known. "No, the prime minister is not considering, he is not assessing, he is not supporting or opposing any idea or proposal until he is convinced that the Palestinians understand what lies before them and are ready with courage and responsibility to make painful decisions," Yaniv said.

Justice Minister Yossi Beilin, an architect of the interim peace agreements that led to the marathon summit outside Washington, said years of paying homage to "a unified Jerusalem; had become a burden Israel should no longer bear. "These villages are not really ours," Beilin told Israel army radio, speaking of Arab neighborhoods in the eastern part of the city, captured by Israel in the 1967 Mideast war. "We must not allow this mirage to become an obstruction to Ehud Barak to arrive at the dream of peace with the Palestinians, now so close."

Jerusalem nearly scuttled the marathon talks last week, but Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat agreed, at the behest of US President Bill Clinton, to extend their stay. They are negotiating the core issues that have so far stymied lower-level negotiators: Jerusalem, borders and refugees.

Jerusalem, with its sites holy to Judaism, Islam and Christianity, is by far the most sensitive issue. Palestinians insist on full sovereignty in east Jerusalem.

Beilin said the neighborhoods in question could become part of the Palestinian state Arafat has pledged to declare this year. Ariel Sharon, the leader of the hard-line opposition Likud party, told Israel radio that giving up such neighborhoods would isolate Jewish areas and subject them to the dangers of Palestinian attack.

Yaniv acknowledged that there would be hard, painful concessions to be made at Camp David if the sides were to come to an agreement.

"There is a heavy atmosphere as we face a historic decision," he said, describing it as a choice between "ending 100 years of bloodshed; or allowing the conflict to deteriorate into more violence.

Many Arabs say that Arafat needs to hold firm on Jerusalem, because the city is not holy only for the Palestinians, but for hundreds of millions of Muslims as well. In Lebanon, Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, a spiritual of the militantly anti-Israel Hezbollah, said Arafat "does not have the authority to change history, or humiliate Jerusalem.

"Any concession ... amounts to a betrayal of the historic trust that every Arab and Muslim carries with him," Fadlallah said.

webTitle: Villa turn to £4.7m Turkish defender

fields.headline: Villa turn to £4.7m Turkish defender
fields.trailText: Aston Villa yesterday welcomed the Turkish defender Alpay Ozalan to Birmingham for talks about a £4.7m move but immediately tried to play down the notion that any deal would see the unsettled Ugo Ehiogu heading for the door.
fields.body:
Aston Villa yesterday welcomed the Turkish defender Alpay Ozalan to Birmingham for talks about a £4.7m move but immediately tried to play down the notion that any deal would see the unsettled Ugo Ehiogu heading for the door.

Alpay, 27 and with 49 caps, spent last season playing for Fenerbahce while on loan from Siirt Jet-Pa Spor and would need a work permit. However, the receipt of one would appear a formality, and he is expected to agree a four-year deal.

"He's got a lot of good qualities, he is comfortable on the ball and good in the air," said Villa's manager John Gregory. "[But] I will be quite happy if Ugo sits out the remaining two years of his contract. As far as I am concerned he is not going anywhere."

Gregory turned down Manchester City's £6m offer for Ehiogu earlier this week, and has also rejected a Wimbledon approach for Paul Merson.

Alpay has been a regular for Turkey since making his debut in 1995, though he was dismissed for punching Portugal's Fernando Couto in the first half of their Euro 2000 quarter-final defeat. A few days later, en route to a reception staged by the Turkish FA, he also had a punch-up with an Istanbul taxi-driver who accused him of being "a traitor" for getting sent off.

"We are proud of sending our player to Aston Villa, which is one of the biggest soccer clubs in the world," was the view of Takiddin Yarayan, Siirt Jet-Pa Spor's chairman.

Bolton, who completed a £4m deal to sell the 23-year-old Claus Jensen to Charlton, almost immediately went out and bought another Danish midfielder, Blackburn's Per Frandsen, 29, for £1.65m and only 10 months after selling him to the Ewood Park club for £1.7m. Bradford are expecting to sign Nicky Summerbee from Sunderland for £1.5m.

Everton have been granted a work permit for the Ghana midfielder Alex Nyarko after only five days and are expecting the Denmark midfielder Thomas Gravesen, 24, to fly in for a medical today in readiness for a £2.5m move from Hamburg.

The Merseysiders have also announced that their feasibility study into redeveloping Goodison Park revealed that any revamp would restrict expansion plans. The site for their likely 55,000-seat new stadium is expected to be at King's Dock, on the river.

Robbie Fowler will lead the Liverpool team out this season as Jamie Redknapp will be absent until at least Christmas with a knee problem. "If Robbie plays he is captain," said Gérard Houllier, the Anfield club's manager. "Otherwise Sami [Hypia] will step in."

Leicester's £6.5m-rated Neil Lennon claims that Celtic have made a bid for him and said that he intends to discuss his situation with the club, who have persuaded his fellow midfielder Muzzy Izzet to sign a new four-year deal.

 Steve Archibald, the former Spurs and Scotland striker, is the new owner of First Division Airdrie. He immediately named the former Blackburn manager Dave Mackay as director of football.

webTitle: Brought to its knees by rich and powerful

fields.headline: Brought to its knees by rich and powerful
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Equitable Life has been brought to its knees by some of the richest and most powerful policyholders in Britain, including top lawyers, high court judges, investment bankers and university professors.
fields.body:
Equitable Life has been brought to its knees by some of the richest and most powerful policyholders in Britain, including top lawyers, high court judges, investment bankers and university professors.

The action was brought by former stockbroker David Hyman. Yesterday he said: "It's sad that a company as old as Equitable should finish in this way, but they brought it upon themselves. I'm delighted at the victory. We felt we had been very badly treated and the courts have found this to be the case."

Michael Simmons, a partner at high-profile law firm Finers Stephens Innocent, is another of Equitable's wealthy clients. A holder of one of the disputed guaranteed policies, his pension income will go up by about £25,000 a year to £115,000 from £90,000 as a result of the ruling. The figures suggest his Equitable policy will be worth around £1m on retirement.

Yesterday he blamed Equitable's management for the failure of the court action and decision to seek a buyer. He said: "I do feel sad. Equitable was a great society, but it treated us as if we didn't exist.

"I went to the AGM and the arrogance of the board was breathtaking. They must have spent around £500,000 on a ridiculous legal dispute, even though we sought to negotiate with them. They all ought now to resign... The chief executive should fall on his sword."

Stuart Bayliss, managing director of Annuity Direct, organised the 1,500-strong Equitable policyholders' action group.

"Equitable has an amazingly high net worth client base who chose the company because of its low charges and great performance," he said. "They loved Equitable and they want to love it again. But unfortunately the company brought this upon themselves."

Unanimous ruling

The law lords yesterday ruled 5-0 in favour of the policyholders in their legal battle against Equitable Life:

 90,000 holders of guaranteed annuity rate policies will get both their guarantee, an annuity rate of about 11% rather than the prevailing 8%, and the full terminal bonus

 GAR policyholders who have already taken their benefits since the mid-1990s are likely to receive backdated compensation

 The 500,000 policyholders without GAR policies face lower overall bonuses, which are planned to be offset by the sale proceeds of the company

 Policy values quoted in the December 31 1999 statements to policyholders will still apply. Managing director Alan Nash said: "Non-GAR policies are likely to be hit by this judgement, but we do not expect policy values to fall below the level of December 31."

webTitle: Theatre review: Alice through the Looking Glass

fields.headline: Upon reflection
fields.standfirst:
Alice Through the Looking Glass
Peacock Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.trailText:
Alice Through the Looking Glass
Peacock Theatre, Dublin
****
fields.body:
Lewis Carroll's Alice tales have been adapted to death, but here the Sligo-based physical theatre troupe Blue Raincoats have created a weirdly affecting 90-minute piece, which is running in rep with their earlier Adventures in Wonderland.

There is some initial awkwardness with the narrative-laden text of Jocelyn Clarke's adaptation, a lot of it shouldered by Alice (played by Fiona McGeown). The reliance on narrative sometimes impedes the visual flow of a low-lit production that offers many beautiful images. There are some clever tricks: the cast spilling from three gargantuan suitcases; the head-out-of-a-box shorthand for Humpty Dumpty; the dream-continuity between the railway carriage, the baa-ing wool shop and Dodgson's poem of gliding with Alice down the river.

McGeown's Alice is an imperious little madam, resisting the conundrums of the Looking Glass creatures; under Niall Henry's direction, she nicely registers the fear of not being real. Doubling as the Knight - teetering stiffly astride a wooden horse - David Heap plays a pained, slightly sinister Dodgson, a complex, cold presence, but scarcely suggesting the awful ghoul of paedophilia. The mystery is sharpened by Alice's bewilderment as Mrs Hargreaves in later life, puzzling over a letter asking for permission to publish the story created in her name.

There is something of Morton Cohen's recent biography here, if not quite the latter's thesis that Alice's adventures represent Dodgson's own journey in indulging, repressing and transcending his unmentionable desires. But the company maintains the wistful innocence of the books, adding some real emotion and wise little puffs of humour.

In rep until August 12. Box office: 00-353-1-8787222.

webTitle: Art review: Mario Rossi

fields.headline: Painting the final frame
fields.standfirst:
Mario Rossi
Cornerhouse, Mancheste
***
fields.trailText:
Mario Rossi
Cornerhouse, Mancheste
***
fields.body:
Walking out after a matinee film screening can be a profoundly disillusioning experience. The painter Mario Rossi appears transfixed by this moment of abrupt awakening. Over a two-year period, he has painted one hundred canvases depicting the final frames of one hundred films. Under the brilliant skylights of the Cornerhouse's refurbished top-floor gallery, his composite work, The End, Untitled 1999, fills the walls. Each 2 ft x 3 ft panel captures the exact moment a drama fades to nothing.

The first shows a couple embracing in a sepia haze. The last is a glimpse of a train disappearing across a landscape of nauseous green. The End is superimposed over each image in varying script. Occasionally there are brief further credits - sometimes there's a hint of the art film: "Fin, Fine, Finis." Otherwise all significance is meticulously obscured.

Rossi appears to go to great pains to avoid a cataloguing of cult or kitsch classics. Most of the images call out for climax music but it is the silence of the exhibition that is striking. The arrangement fails to add up to any narrative or even surreal resolution. There's a speed-boat powering away, a Rorschach blot, a plane taking off, a close-up of a lizard, a moonlit galleon, a hammer-and-sickle, a cat hunting toy American Indians. There are scenes of departure, but locations are a long way from anywhere in particular.

Overall, these blurred projections add up to an almost blasé minimalism. They leave us self-consciously aware of our desire for illusions. They leave us with no illusions by suggesting that everything is projected illusion.

Until August 6. Box office: 0161-228 7621.

webTitle: Jazz review: James Carter

fields.headline: Intensity, no deliberation
fields.standfirst:
James Carter
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.trailText:
James Carter
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.body:
James Carter, the 31-year-old Detroit saxophonist, has been building a reputation for awesome originality since he emerged in the early 90s, and though he isn't as big a star as his contemporary Joshua Redman, he deserves to be. Carter's performances are compelling, earthy, ferocious and risky. Considering how much he relies on variations on the traditions, that is an indication of how powerful an imagination and technique he has.

He's at his best when his rugged mix of free-sax blasting, fundamentalist funk and talkative lyricism is pushed by performers as dominant as him. At this gig he was in about the best setting he could have found: Kelvyn Bell joined him on guitar, Jamaaladeen Tacuma on bass and Calvin Weston on drums.

The most magnetic feature of the fluid, intense set was the absence of self-conscious deliberation, as the ingredients of 20th-century black American music were hurled together and torn apart. Bell played a delicate Broadway guitar ballad, turned it into a funky rhythm-shuffle, then a passage of free-guitar pushed it aside. James Carter arrived in this at his most extreme then eased into a breezy funk. Switching from alto to tenor, Carter played Good Morning Heartache beautifully, with voluptuous smears over lazy swing, then reprofiled it as a Latin dance groove. It was like listening to a jazz history lesson - but not recollected in tranquillity, rather the opposite.

webTitle: Equitable sale may net up to £4bn

fields.headline: Equitable sale may net up to £4bn
fields.standfirst:
City stunned as oldest mutual goes on market after House of Lords defeat
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank and Dutch insurer Aegon were last night at the front of a queue of buyers for Equitable Life in an auction that could attract bids as high as £4bn and hand windfalls averaging £4,000 or more to policyholders.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank and Dutch insurer Aegon were last night at the front of a queue of buyers for Equitable Life in an auction that could attract bids as high as £4bn and hand windfalls averaging £4,000 or more to policyholders.

Equitable, Britain's oldest mutual, stunned the City yesterday morning when it put itself up for sale within minutes of a House of Lords ruling against the company which will cost it up to £1.5bn.

The law lords ruled that Equitable had acted illegally in banning 90,000 policyholders from enjoying the full benefits of guaranteed annuity rates that were sold in policies from the 1950s to the 1980s.

Before the ruling, Equitable insisted that the cost would be no more than £200m, but yesterday admitted the true cost would be closer to £1.5bn.

Managing director Alan Nash said: "We are now obliged to give a much larger number of people much better benefits. Mutuality has served us well, but the fact of the matter is that at 10.30am the goalposts moved and Equitable has to accept it."

Barclays was cited as front of the queue of any British bidders for Equitable, which has £33bn under management and 600,000 policyholders.

A takeover of Equitable Life would allow Matt Barrett, the new chief executive of Barclays who made his mark in Canada as a dealmaker, take his first strategic step since assuming the helm nine months ago. Barclays refused to comment.

Aegon, which already owns Scottish Equitable, said yesterday that it planned further acquisitions. "We have made no secret of the fact that we aim to be a top five player in the UK," said a spokesman.

Standard Life, long rumoured as a potential mutual partner for Equitable, is believed to have ruled itself out of the bidding battle, and Mr Nash said that the sale will almost certainly be to a proprietary company rather than a mutual.

Major corporate finance houses were last night clambering over each other to secure the mandates from banks and insurers to start bidding for Equitable.

One corporate financier said last night the list of buyers could also include CGNU, Prudential, Allianz, Generali and Axa. But Halifax is believed to be out of the frame, given recent acquisitions, and Legal & General is said to be determined to grow organically

Analysts are pencilling in a bid price of about £4bn, which will produce a windfall of £2.5bn for policyholders once £1.5bn is spent to prop up Equitable's long-term funds after higher annuity payouts.

The bidding battle is expected to be swift. Independent life industry analyst Ned Cazalet said: "They will need to find a buyer very quickly.

"Equitable has a fantastically successful sales force, and Allied Dunbar and others will be on the phone to them immediately if they have any sense. They'll want to get the sale process over as soon as possible to stop the company being blighted."

Equitable, which is based in Aylesbury and has 2,000 employees, is renowned as the most efficient, no commission-paying company in the industry, with sales per head 10 times higher than many rivals. Mr Cazalet believes any buyer will reverse its existing life operations into Equitable to take advantage of its low cost base.

But its policy of paying out high bonuses means that it has limited excess reserves, thereby restricting the scope for any large windfalls.

However, one leading life company said last night that the court battle has reduced Equitable's attractiveness. "Everyone will be looking at it but will be asking if the brand is still intact, or whether it has been mortally damaged."

Barclays refused to comment. Aegon, which already owns Scottish Equitable, said yesterday that it planned further acquisitions. "We have made no secret of the fact that we aim to be a top five player in the UK," said a spokesman. Standard Life, long rumoured as a potential mutual partner for Equitable, is believed to have ruled itself out of the bidding battle, and Mr Nash said that the sale will almost certainly be to a proprietary company rather than a mutual. Major corporate finance houses were last night clambering over each other to secure the mandates from banks and insurers to start bidding for Equitable. One corporate financier said last night the list of buyers could also include CGNU, Prudential, Allianz, Generali and Axa. But Halifax is believed to be out of the frame, given recent acquisitions, and Legal & General is said to be determined to grow organically Analysts are pencilling in a bid price of about £4bn, which will produce a windfall of £2.5bn for policyholders once £1.5bn is spent to prop up Equitable's long-term funds after higher annuity payouts. The bidding battle is expected to be swift. Independent life industry analyst Ned Cazalet said: "They will need to find a buyer very quickly. "Equitable has a fantastically successful sales force, and Allied Dunbar and others will be on the phone to them immediately if they have any sense. They'll want to get the sale process over as soon as possible to stop the company being blighted." Equitable, which is based in Aylesbury and has 2,000 employees, is renowned as the most efficient, no commission-paying company in the industry, with sales per head 10 times higher than many rivals. Mr Cazalet believes any buyer will reverse its existing life operations into Equitable to take advantage of its low cost base. But its policy of paying out high bonuses means that it has limited excess reserves, thereby restricting the scope for any large windfalls. However, one leading life company said last night that the court battle has reduced Equitable's attractiveness. "Everyone will be looking at it but will be asking if the brand is still intact, or whether it has been mortally damaged."

webTitle: Pop review: Karyn Black

fields.headline: Ham-fisted perplexity
fields.standfirst:
Karyn Black
Borderline, London
*
fields.trailText:
Karyn Black
Borderline, London
*
fields.body:
Although Karyn Black is feted in country circles for her album Beneath the Sheltering Sky, this performance was an object lesson in the importance of being prepared. The sight of her guitarist and bass player squinting at chord changes written on a piece of paper while Black nervously strummed the introduction to the next song scarcely inspired confidence. Apparently they'd had three days' rehearsal, but it didn't seem to have helped much since Black spent most of the show wearing an expression of weary perplexity.

When she was searching for pathos the performance descended into farce, as her ham-fisted drummer blundered about during the quiet bits. Every time the tempo was upped a few notches, guitarist Bobby Cochrane took a warp-speed solo. A shame for Karyn, obviously, who did drop the occasional hint that she might be a decent songwriter. Crystal Clear was agreeably melodic if over-sensitive, while the band managed to scrape together a semblance of togetherness during Beneath the Sheltering Sky itself.

It was difficult to see why Black gets filed under country rather than folk. Like the Wild Seas fits squarely into the latter category, as do Black's questionable excursions into cod-Irish jiggery. This wasn't the sort of performance to make you want to investigate any further.

webTitle: Accountants demand inquiry into loss of tax records

fields.headline: Accountants demand inquiry into loss of tax records
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The body representing the accountancy profession yesterday called for a parliamentary investigation into the inland revenue after the disclosure that 5.2m taxpayers' files have been lost.
fields.body:
The body representing the accountancy profession yesterday called for a parliamentary investigation into the inland revenue after the disclosure that 5.2m taxpayers' files have been lost.

The Association of Chartered Certified Accountants, or ACCA, says it is impossible for the government to crack down on tardy taxpayers while the inland revenue fails to put its own house in order. Chas Roy-Chowdhury, head of taxation at ACCA, said: "It is time that parliament looked into this sorry state of affairs.

"The revenue is always saying 'sorry'. But someone needs to take the problem by the scruff of the neck and sort it out, and we need a timetable for doing so."

The latest embarrassment for the government department was highlighted in a memo seen by the Guardian.

The revenue yesterday admitted that "there remain some 5.2m taxpayer records for which no 1998-1999 pay and tax details are held on COP [computerised operation of the pay-as-you-earn system]."

An inland revenue spokesman confirmed that the details could not be located but insisted they had not been "lost in cyberspace" forever but were temporarily missing.

ACCA says this is only one in a series of mistakes which have served seriously to undermine the credbility of the tax collection system in the eyes of taxpayers and professionals alike.

According to Mr Roy-Chowdhury the main problems have been:

 Malfunctions shut down the computerised self-assessment service for six weeks from the start of this tax year on April 6;

 1.8m tax return forms issued last year with incorrect dates;

 750,000 incorrect tax demands made last year;

 Incorrect assessments of penalties over the last three years because the computers did not pick up correct tax details.

He believes continued computer crashes at the inland revenue could leave millions out of pocket as rebates are delayed for months at a time, leaving taxpayers losing out on possible interest payments.

Ten days ago the govern ment department admitted that computer problems meant that a significant backlog had developed but said that its national IT section was trying to tackle the problem.

At the centre of the latest problems are two computer systems which have been handed over to two private companies: Andersen Consulting and EDS. It is thought the 5.2m files disappeared while being transferred between the two.

webTitle: First lesson for one-to-one teaching: establish rapport

fields.headline: First lesson for one-to-one teaching: establish rapport
fields.trailText: Those that teach, if they do it well, know the value of rapport. Some teachers have it as a sixth sense. To others it is seen as a buzz word. Yet to most people rapport is a way to achieve the results they want. Teachers need to have an ability to obtain rapport, both with a group of 15-year-olds or with just one student.
fields.body:
Those that teach, if they do it well, know the value of rapport. Some teachers have it as a sixth sense. To others it is seen as a buzz word. Yet to most people rapport is a way to achieve the results they want. Teachers need to have an ability to obtain rapport, both with a group of 15-year-olds or with just one student.

In one-to-one teaching, however, rapport is vital. The teacher has to make the learner feel at ease, to allow them to lose their inhibitions and to build a relationship with them for a specific period of time.

Building rapport is a two-way process. Remember that you need also to be at ease. Learners are with you to learn language and also the culture of communication. The aim is to achieve a situation in which you and your student are comfortable and motivated.

Closely linked to rapport is empathy. To obtain true rapport with another person or a group you need to have an empathic feeling towards them, or at least make them think that.

Our success at establishing rapport with others is determined by our behavioural attitudes and the particular situation we are in at any given moment. Teachers therefore need to be good judges of their students' mood and also know in advance about the kind of behaviour that is appropriate in their culture. There are, however, certain general techniques that can prove useful in achieving rapport.

Mirroring

This is a strong way to establish a link with another person. It can be done very successfully with individuals. The process is simple but needs care, as too much too soon can be interpreted as patronising or making fun and could easily lead to the opposite of the desired effect.

Try this exercise. Sit opposite or adjacent to someone you do not know well. While talking, take up a similar posture to them. Note where their hands are; note how they have positioned their legs, the angle of their body. Mirror their positions. If their legs are crossed, cross yours, if they are leaning forward or back then follow them.

After a while you can begin to take the lead by changing your body posture slightly, not overtly. If they then follow, you have achieved a symbiosis of movement. It is also likely that by this time your discussions will have become more dynamic or intense and your relationship will have grown.

Modulating your voice

Once you are comfortable with working with mirroring posture you can then turn to the voice. The tone and pitch of your voice can be matched to that of your student.

Try this exercise. Have a normal conversation with a colleague, begin to get a little heated, raise your voice, note what happens. Your colleague's voice will probably also rise (unless they are a submissive type in which case they may just avoid confrontation). If their voice rises, raise yours another notch. Observe if they follow. If they do, then bring your voice back down and watch the effect.

Know your student

Learn about the personal space of your student's culture. It is essential that you do not work too close or too far away. Discover if touch is taboo. What is the meaning of eye contact in their culture? Should there be eye contact? In some cultures the student does not look at the teacher.

Formality of behaviour is often linked to age, but not always. If your student is older than you be aware of formality and learn the proper forms of address from their culture Be aware also of how your student may be used to being taught. Is it similar to the way you teach? If not, take this into consideration. Find out their learning style and adapt your teaching style to support it.

Finally, although discussing family life may be a wonderful opportunity to develop language do be aware of any taboos the student may have in their culture and act accordingly.

Obtaining rapport is one of a range of techniques and procedures that will help you to work with other people from all walks of life. Rapport involves changing the way you are perceived and the way you perceive others. Then you can start to build relationships that will grow and last.

 John Markson-Brown is an ELT trainer

webTitle: Britain swaps Mandarin for English in its bid to teach China

fields.headline: Britain swaps Mandarin for English in its bid to teach China
fields.standfirst: David Blunkett, Britain's education minister, outlines plans for linguistic exchange with mass appeal
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, Britain's education minister, outlines plans for linguistic exchange with mass appeal.
fields.body:
I recently visited China where more than a quarter of the population are studying in one form or another - more than 320m people.

I know that one of Britain's most important assets is the English language. All over the world millions of people are studying English as they know that it is vital if they want to succeed. We are lucky to have been given this massive advantage and it's important that we realise how valuable a commodity our language is. We need to work with countries such as China to take full advantage of future commercial partnerships. This means not only supporting the teaching of English in China, but exploring the possibilities for teaching Chinese in English schools.

There are more people learning English in China than there are native speakers of English in the world. The British Council has been promoting British excellence in ELT and research, and has developed strategic partnerships between British and Chinese university ELT departments.

The Chinese government invited me to visit to discuss our plans for new developments in Britain and China. Mme Chen Zhili, China's education minister, and I signed a wide-ranging framework education agreement that will give a push to bilateral relations in education and training and encourage the blossoming co-operation and partnerships between Britain and China.

The Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has granted the British Council's Central Bureau for International Education and Training £300,000 ($450,000) over a three-year period to develop strategic partnerships for the benefit of Mandarin teaching and learning in Britain. During my visit I announced a £130,000 ($195,000) contribution over three years from HSBC (the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation) to the Central Bureau to expand the teaching of Mandarin Chinese in British secondary schools. This is a significant contribution towards developing a cohort of British students able to speak Mandarin. It will increase opportunities for education and economic links between both countries. Interest is growing among secondary schools for partnerships with schools in China, and in the teaching of Mandarin Chinese, and we want to encourage this. I very much hope that additional resources will also be found in the future to promote the teaching of Mandarin Chinese.

Since the early 1980s Britain has been closely involved in many aspects of English language teaching development in China. China is well on the way to becoming a member of the World Trade Organisation, and Chinese markets will therefore soon begin to be open to exporters from the rest of the world. We hope to build on our history of partnership with China and see more opportunities for public and private sector English language providers in both countries to work together.

I visited the Foreign Enterprises Service Company (Fesco) in Beijing, a large-scale international service trading corporation that provides human resources and services for foreign and joint-venture enterprises. It acts as the agent and examination centre for the London Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Beijing, offering qualifications in a range of subjects, including English. It is also one of the key centres involved in a pilot project that the British Council has been running since 1997 to help China develop its own CNVQs closely linked to Britain's National Vocational Qualification (NVQ) model. In Beijing I visited China Central Radio and TV University, where Chinese and British experts have developed China's first distance learning degree for English language teachers.

Proficiency in English is a development tool for economic growth. The Shanghai municipal government is working to strengthen the teaching and learning of English throughout schools in Shanghai. These include the extension of English teaching to primary school students from age seven from 2001, and the pilot introduction of Oxford University Press materials in seven districts, and the introduction of an oral English component to university entrance exams.

All this will present new challenges for teachers. I met English teachers who had attended a trainers' programme in English language teaching at Lancaster University as part of Shanghai's scheme to upgrade the language skills and teaching capacity of its secondary school teachers. I was glad to hear their positive individual evaluations of the course and their favourable impressions of studying in England. To date a total of 67 teachers have benefited from the training, with plans for a further 50 to be trained in the current year.

China has 7m teachers and 700,000 schools. These projects could have an enormous effect on the teaching of English in China, which we must support. The benefits for everyone - English teachers, Chinese students and Britain's international standing - are tremendous.

 David Blunkett is the Secretary of State for Education and Employment.

webTitle: Put your best ideas on the shelf

fields.headline: Put your best ideas on the shelf
fields.standfirst: If you can't find the right book, write it yourself. Susan Norman advises teachers on how to get published
fields.trailText: If you can't find the right book, write it yourself. Susan Norman advises teachers on how to get published.
fields.body:
If you want to become an EFL writer the best and most often repeated advice is have something to say. Good books spring from good ideas that are based on good practice. As ELT editor Jeremy Harmer puts it: "As a teacher, one of the best reasons for writing EFL books is that you're dissatisfied with what's on offer, so you write material for your own students."

Most people start by sitting down and writing the book in their spare time - every minute of it for quite a long time. This is a sensible approach, particularly with a first book. It proves that you've got the ability and the discipline to write a book, you will have a full "draft" to present to potential publishers, and you will know that this is really what you want to do. The description of writing as "1% inspiration, 99% perspiration" is no exaggeration.

If you don't write the complete book, the very least a publisher will require is a detailed contents list, a sample unit or two, and a marketing brief saying exactly who you think will buy it. Bear in mind, though, that a published book often differs greatly from the original idea. It evolves as you write, and sometimes it is only when you get to the end of the first draft that you will find out what it is you wanted to say.

Writer Robert O'Neill tells how once, more than 20 years ago, when he responded to the pleas of a publisher to "plan the whole book first and then stick to the plan", he produced a draft that, "made me want to vomit. I read it through on the train on my way to my London publisher and realised it was rubbish. As I walked to my appointment I stopped in the middle of a bridge over the Thames and threw the manuscript into the river.

Jane Revell, another seasoned ELT author, never throws anything away. "Keep everything you write, even if at the time of writing you think it's a load of rubbish. Often a bit or reworking or rewording will turn it into a gem." Or maybe you can use it in your next book. Revell also gives some practical ideas on how to go about the writing itself. "Don't just sit there. Write something. Write anything. Once you get started, ideas begin to flow and you can go back and improve on things later. Keep a notebook with you at all times and jot down ideas when they come to you, so you've got something to start with when you do come to write."

Writing the book, however, is only the first stage. It needs to be edited, designed and printed, which is a process normally determined by publishers. Their treatment of your text will influenced by crucial considerations such as sales and distribution, No matter how good a book is, if it doesn't reach the attention of people who might want to buy it, the exercise will have been a costly and time-consuming failure.

Many of the publisher's decision will be based on cost. Every page costs more money, but many of their suggestions will relate to making this a better book. As writer Ingrid Freebairn says, "Don't think you know best. Listen to the editors. This is a team effort." Jeremy Harmer agrees: "Many of the best books have owed their success partly to the editorial work that has gone on as the manuscripts have progressed."

Whether or not you have an editor, take a professional view of your writing. Very often it is the phrase you love best that needs to come out. Keep checking that you're still on track. Think about what the audience wants. "Make sure it works," as Ingrid Freebairn advises. "Pretend you are a student or a bored teacher. Answer the questions yourself, be your own testing ground."

With a draft written you then need choose (or find) a publisher. Start by looking for publishers that seem to publish similar works to yours (look along the shelves of an EFL bookshop - addresses are usually on the inside cover of books). Publishers will not usually publish something that competes directly with a current title unless it is past its sell-by date, but they may take something which complements an existing title. You may also benefit from "me-too" publishing, where a publisher produces a book similar to something by another publisher that sells well.

If you are really breaking new ground, you either need a big publisher that can afford to take the financial risk, or a very small publisher that is prepared to put a lot of individual effort into marketing. Alternatively, you can publish it yourself - but that is another story.

Never underestimate the role played by chance. As so many authors recall, their "big break" with a publisher came from being in the right place at the right time. This is what happened to Ken Wilson, but as he warns, "you can't possibly predict when that right place and right time might be. As a young teacher, I was playing a song I had written for my class. A director of studies heard it, someone told Longmans and within a matter of months I was a published ELT author. I was 23."

If you're good, the word will get out. But there is also plenty you can do to get yourself noticed. Present your ideas at teachers' seminars and conferences - most teachers' associations invite their members to put forward suggestions for lectures and papers. Start by writing for specialist ELT periodicals and magazines - at least it proves you can write. In this way you will get your name known.

Often publishers will approach you. They are, after all, always in need of material to publish, and many publishers set about building a list, and they look for authors for specific books they want to commission. My first EFL book came about because I was commercial English director at one of the big London schools, and Longmans asked me to submit a synopsis for business English materials.

Be warned, though. Writing is hard work and time-consuming. It is a bit like getting married or having a baby. If you really knew what was involved, you'd probably leave it to someone else. But don't let that put you off. The arrival of the copies of that book bearing your name makes the whole thing worthwhile - and very few of us ever stop at just the one.

 Susan Norman is an ELT author

As I walked to my appointment I stopped in the middle of a bridge over the Thames and threw the manuscript into the river. Jane Revell, another seasoned ELT author, never throws anything away. "Keep everything you write, even if at the time of writing you think it's a load of rubbish. Often a bit or reworking or rewording will turn it into a gem." Or maybe you can use it in your next book. Revell also gives some practical ideas on how to go about the writing itself. "Don't just sit there. Write something. Write anything. Once you get started, ideas begin to flow and you can go back and improve on things later. Keep a notebook with you at all times and jot down ideas when they come to you, so you've got something to start with when you do come to write." Writing the book, however, is only the first stage. It needs to be edited, designed and printed, which is a process normally determined by publishers. Their treatment of your text will influenced by crucial considerations such as sales and distribution, No matter how good a book is, if it doesn't reach the attention of people who might want to buy it, the exercise will have been a costly and time-consuming failure. Many of the publisher's decision will be based on cost. Every page costs more money, but many of their suggestions will relate to making this a better book. As writer Ingrid Freebairn says, "Don't think you know best. Listen to the editors. This is a team effort." Jeremy Harmer agrees: "Many of the best books have owed their success partly to the editorial work that has gone on as the manuscripts have progressed." Whether or not you have an editor, take a professional view of your writing. Very often it is the phrase you love best that needs to come out. Keep checking that you're still on track. Think about what the audience wants. "Make sure it works," as Ingrid Freebairn advises. "Pretend you are a student or a bored teacher. Answer the questions yourself, be your own testing ground." With a draft written you then need choose (or find) a publisher. Start by looking for publishers that seem to publish similar works to yours (look along the shelves of an EFL bookshop - addresses are usually on the inside cover of books). Publishers will not usually publish something that competes directly with a current title unless it is past its sell-by date, but they may take something which complements an existing title. You may also benefit from "me-too" publishing, where a publisher produces a book similar to something by another publisher that sells well. If you are really breaking new ground, you either need a big publisher that can afford to take the financial risk, or a very small publisher that is prepared to put a lot of individual effort into marketing. Alternatively, you can publish it yourself - but that is another story. Never underestimate the role played by chance. As so many authors recall, their "big break" with a publisher came from being in the right place at the right time. This is what happened to Ken Wilson, but as he warns, "you can't possibly predict when that right place and right time might be. As a young teacher, I was playing a song I had written for my class. A director of studies heard it, someone told Longmans and within a matter of months I was a published ELT author. I was 23." If you're good, the word will get out. But there is also plenty you can do to get yourself noticed. Present your ideas at teachers' seminars and conferences - most teachers' associations invite their members to put forward suggestions for lectures and papers. Start by writing for specialist ELT periodicals and magazines - at least it proves you can write. In this way you will get your name known. Often publishers will approach you. They are, after all, always in need of material to publish, and many publishers set about building a list, and they look for authors for specific books they want to commission. My first EFL book came about because I was commercial English director at one of the big London schools, and Longmans asked me to submit a synopsis for business English materials. Be warned, though. Writing is hard work and time-consuming. It is a bit like getting married or having a baby. If you really knew what was involved, you'd probably leave it to someone else. But don't let that put you off. The arrival of the copies of that book bearing your name makes the whole thing worthwhile - and very few of us ever stop at just the one.  Susan Norman is an ELT author

webTitle: Bicknell thrives on Major workload

fields.headline: Bicknell thrives on Major workload
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire 313-9  v Surrey
fields.trailText: Leicestershire 313-9 v Surrey
fields.body:
As the most inoffensive prime minister of modern times, few would begrudge John Major some pleasure in his dotage, even if he does insist on wearing pink shirts. In his presidential year, indeed, he may well derive more from another Surrey title than he ever did from his profession. Watching Martin Bicknell restrict Leicestershire to an under-par score, therefore, was probably fairly close to his idea of heaven.

Bicknell's six for 70, a season's best, took his summer's tally to 42, the most by an England-qualified bowler. It was a manful contribution rendered all the more admirable by the absence of Alex Tudor, still stricken by a side strain, and the shoulder injury that confined Ian Salisbury to the outfield until 6.20.

Salisbury's selection tells you all you need to know about the leaders' state of mind. To enter a match against one of your keenest rivals with three fit frontline bowlers - Ben Hollioake has yet to qualify - suggests a self-belief bordering on the reckless. Then again, when you have beaten those selfsame opponents by an innings and plenty, as they did a fortnight ago, respect can be elusive.

Wise enough not to try to emulate his father's predilection for batting, Carl Greenidge shared the new ball, fusing Michael Holding's approach with Keith Boyce's delivery. But it was Bicknell, inevitably, who made the ini tial incisions by disposing of the two Darrens in successive overs, Maddy caught behind via an airy waft, Stevens chipping a return catch, lulled like so many into believing that that menacing rumble to the crease portends something rather more rapid.

Cue Ben Smith, whose century against Durham last week ended a run of 15 four-day innings without a fifty. In the pennant-deciding match at the Oval two years ago he made 204, albeit without having to contend with Saqlain Mushtaq, who came here boasting 35 wickets in his previous four outings.

Playing immaculately forward, bat perpendicular, spin stifled, Smith tackled him with something akin to nonchalance. He was twice spared before reaching 20, if one can so describe his reprieves. Whereas Mark Butcher is too good a fielder not to regard a tricky slip chance off Hollioake as being within his compass, Greenidge created something out of nothing, soaring to parry a mis-hook then plunging only to see the ball dribble from his grasp. These blemishes aside, Smith was the soul of composure, the first hundred against the champions this term his undoubted due.

There were four half-century stands, the most authoritative by Smith and Aftab Habib, Saqlain's only victim in his first 35 overs, the highest and most vibrant by Phil DeFreitas and Dominic Williamson. The pitch showed no claws; what havoc Alistair Brown might cause on it today.

webTitle: King-sized hitch in Windies rebuilding

fields.headline: King-sized hitch in Windies rebuilding
fields.trailText: There is a large sign here advertising "FG Skerritt Ltd Total Building Services". Ricky Skerritt, the West Indies manager, may not be part of the family but maybe he should consult them about reconstructing the West Indies team without the creaking girders that are Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose.
fields.body:
There is a large sign here advertising "FG Skerritt Ltd Total Building Services". Ricky Skerritt, the West Indies manager, may not be part of the family but maybe he should consult them about reconstructing the West Indies team without the creaking girders that are Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose.

Without these two the team have collapsed as suddenly and completely as a detonated building. They have lost all four of the matches they have completed in the NatWest triangular series, some heavily, and appear to have lost much of the form and confidence that saw them beat England so thoroughly in the opening Test at Edgbaston.

"We haven't played this series very well," Skerritt admitted. "But then we haven't played one-day cricket very well for some years.

"Our biggest concern coming into this series was the lack of leadership we saw from the young fast bowlers, having to play without Courtney and Curtly.

"This is a big test for West Indies cricket. Without Courtney and Curtly will the next generation of fast bowlers stand up and be counted? In the Caribbean earlier this year, and again early on this tour, there were signs that this would happen. But based on the way they have performed in this one-day series there are a lot of reasons to be worried.

"But it should be remembered that Reon King came to England at the peak of his career and then suffered a couple of injuries and then a loss of form. I just hope he can peak again before the Tests."

The bowling is not the only worry, however. The batting has been shallow and the fielding simply awful on occasions. Skerritt places some of the blame on the weather. "When we played at Canterbury the players were shocked by how cold it was. They used handwarmers and sent back to the hotel for thermal underwear. I don't want to make excuses. We dropped nine catches and fielded like a juvenile team. But the weather was a factor."

With West Indies already out of Saturday's final, today will count for little in this series and less when Walsh and Ambrose run in at Old Trafford in a couple of weeks' time, but England would be delighted to maintain their momentum after the 10-wicket victory in Durham at the weekend.

Paul Franks could make his England debut on his home ground today. Having toured with the England A side in the winter he is ready to play for the first team should Darren Gough or Andrew Caddick be given a rest.

"I've never bowled better than I have this season," Franks said last night. "I've not been told anything about tomorrow but it's good to be involved in the shake-up."

Alec Stewart has to play, but so far his workload has hardly weighed him down. He scored 101 and took four catches in Tuesday's win over Zimbabwe, despite the indifferent floodlighting at Edgbaston.

"The lights need to improve," he said yesterday. "If you compare them to the lights on grounds in Australia and some in South Africa, then they are just not good enough."

England have lost Vikram Solanki, Robert Croft and Matthew Maynard, who have returned to their counties. Nick Knight remains, but as cover.

West Indies will not rest Brian Lara, despite his sore hamstring. "Brian is struggling a bit," Skerritt said, "but he is playing against England.

The West Indies management is delighted with Lara. "He's been a joy to work with," Skerritt said. "He's very positive, a good team man and he's helped out a lot in team discussions. He seems to be enjoying his cricket.

"We're happy with his form. He's not reached his best yet but the progress has been most satisfactory when you remember that he had not played for five months."

webTitle: Rhodes fights to believe in life after Cronje

fields.headline: Rhodes fights to believe in life after Cronje
fields.trailText: The King Commission may be in recess but the fallout can be seen in some of the key South African players currently enduring the oppressive heat and humidity of the oncoming monsoon season in Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
The King Commission may be in recess but the fallout can be seen in some of the key South African players currently enduring the oppressive heat and humidity of the oncoming monsoon season in Sri Lanka.

It is as if Judge Edwin King's interim report, to be handed to President Mbeki on August 11, is hanging like a sword of Damocles over the heads of some of those players as they go into the first of three Tests against Sri Lanka here today.

The report is only likely to be a factual account of the three-week hearing, and in all likelihood will have little bearing on the team in Sri Lanka, but there will be a huge, collective sigh of relief once the report is published. Perhaps only then will they be able to put the whole issue behind them. For now, though, they must concentrate on playing the game, and on making a start in rehabilitating a game tarnished by the unscrupulous actions of greedy men.

For Jonty Rhodes and Darryl Cullinan the absence of Hansie Cronje seems to be creating problems. The normally easy-going Rhodes is distracted, clearly missing an old friend and confidant. "The closest I've come to Hansie in three months is seeing Pete Sampras play at Wimbledon," Rhodes said, referring to Cronje's physical resemblance to the Wimbledon champion.

But the underlying problem is a real one and, as the longest-serving member of the national team, Rhodes should be more heavily involved in team leadership than he is at the moment.

Cullinan was remote and distant throughout the triangular limited-overs series involving the hosts, Pakistan and South Africa. He struggled to come to terms with the viciously turning pitches and the mystical Muthiah Muralitharan.

On top of that Cullinan is still carrying the embarrassment of a merciless grilling in front of the King Commission. He is battling to focus on his job as the pivotal top-order batsman and this is the series in which he has to stand up and be counted as a world class player for all occasions.

In contrast Gary Kirsten, a distant spectator during the King Commission, has once again looked comfortable on the slower-paced pitches of the subcontinent, finishing as the leading scorer in the limited-overs tournament with 236 runs. But like Rhodes and Cullinan, he appears to be more and more removed from the decision-making role that befits a man of his experience.

Jacques Kallis meanwhile has adapted well with 211 runs in the one-day internationals but the odds are still stacked against South Africa.

Shaun Pollock is well aware of the importance of the next three weeks for the future of his team and his sport. As an all-rounder, the debates will continue concerning his suitability for the captaincy but, as a man with sensitivity and sense, he is comfortably the best man for the job.

Even so, it is likely to take a long time for the sport to regain its place in the hearts and minds of all South Africans.

webTitle: Round-up

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Michael Bevan's purple patch continued yesterday in Hove, where he and Richard Montgomerie made Nottinghamshire pay a heavy price for sending Sussex into bat on the opening day of their Second Division fixture.
fields.body:
Michael Bevan's purple patch continued yesterday in Hove, where he and Richard Montgomerie made Nottinghamshire pay a heavy price for sending Sussex into bat on the opening day of their Second Division fixture.

Their second-wicket partnership was worth 292 out of a total of 404 for five, with each player registering his highest score for the county.

Bevan's share was 166 off 213 balls, made in five hours and including 20 boundaries. The Australian left-hander has now scored 1,493 runs in all cricket this season and 533 in his last seven innings.

It was his second successive championship century, following the unbeaten 151 made in the drawn match against Essex last week, and it will be a source of disappointment for Sussex that they will be without him for 10 days next month when he plays in three one-day internationals against South Africa in Melbourne.

Montgomerie, who had previously passed 50 only three times in first-class cricket this season, made 133 with 19 fours.

Another Australian left-hander, Simon Katich, made his third championship century of the season to provide the basis for Durham's 355 for nine against Lancashire at Old Trafford in the First Division.

Katich, who put on 146 for the third wicket with Paul Collingwood (60), reached his hundred off 157 balls and went on to make 129 before falling to the slow left-arm of Gary Keedy, who took four for 99. England's Chris Schofield was the least successful of Lancashire's three spinners with one for 59.

Yorkshire bowled out Somerset for 182 in Scarborough despite losing their left-arm seamer Ryan Sidebottom, who tore a muscle in his hip after bowling one ball of his fourth over.

At the close the hosts had reached 144 for three, with the young opener Simon Widdup hitting seven boundaries in 44 made from 85 balls in only his second senior game for Yorkshire.

Paul Pollard (77) and David Leatherdale (62) took the batting honours in Chelmsford with a stand of 117 to carry the Second Division leaders Worcestershire to 232 for seven. But the 18-year-old fast bowler Andrew McGarry caught the eye for Essex with three for 29 from 16 overs on his championship debut.

Darren Thomas took five wickets in an innings for the second time this summer as Northamptonshire were dismissed for 229 by Glamorgan in Cardiff.

Thomas's efforts were all the more commendable as his new-ball partner Steve Watkin, who had taken his 800th first-class wicket for Glamorgan with the third ball of the day, limped off with a groin strain in the first over after lunch. Glamorgan themselves were two wickets down by the close.

 Neil Johnson has become the second Zimbabwe player to announce that he is to end his international career. Johnson will return to South Africa as the overseas player for Western Province in a move understood to be influenced by financial and political reasons. Murray Goodwin announced immediately after the recent Zimbabwean elections that he would return to Australia.

webTitle: Warne fulfils a blond ambition

fields.headline: Warne fulfils a blond ambition
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 320
Kent 31-2
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 320
Kent 31-2
fields.body:
The United Services ground is Hampshire's party venue. They win a third of the games they play here - their most successful ground. So, naturally, cricket logic dictates that this will be the last first-class match to take place here.

Still, Hampshire seem determined to say a merry adieu. They knocked up 320 - not bad for a team who have only once before passed 250 in a first innings this year - in a day on a turning pitch, and then had Kent in a spin and five men round the bat within nine overs. Oh, and that Shane Warne chap seems to be enjoying himself.

Warne did not have the best start with the bat when he arrived at Hampshire. Four ducks did not quite match his blond ambition. But here, perhaps inspired by Glenn McGrath's maiden first-class 50 last weekend, he took the sword to Kent - drilling and driving his way to 69.

He was so sure of himself that seconds after playing and missing he repeated his shot for the benefit of the crowd. In fact the only thing he did wrong was to keep his helmet on - swashbuckling heroes aren't quite so swashbuckling if you can't see their face. Not that a cap did Robin Smith much good.

He went to his 50 with a flat-batted six over long on and looked unstoppable until he was foxed by Min Patel, the man who had suffered most at his hands.

Patel, who came on at 12.05, bowled unchanged from the pavilion end for 39.3 overs. He should have been in his element. The man of the moment Marcus Trescothick recently named him the finest left-arm spinner in the country and here he was presented with a nice dry pitch. He did bowl well - in parts. Matthew Walker dropped two catches off him at first slip, but in between being swept repeatedly he beat the bat and managed to spin his way to four wickets. He cuts a boyish figure, all spidery arms and fingers, but he lacks menace as he approaches the crease especially when compared to Warne.

When Warne came on in the fifth over of the Kent reply, he took a wicket with his second ball. Not surprisingly, Rahul Dravid decided that thanks very much but he didn't really fancy coming in for the last four overs. He did not have much choice when David Masters, the nightwatchmen, fell to Warne four balls later.

Poor Jason Laney, who had rehabilitated himself earlier in the day, was forgotten. His highest score in his 11 previous championship innings this season was 19.

But here he was relaxed, driving with ease. He looked on for a hundred until he tried to copy one of Shane Warne's pulls and top-edged to Robert Key.

His face must have been as red as the tips of his ears, which looked as if they needed some sunblock on a day so hot that the bar ran out of ice.

webTitle: Harvey the cream of local artisans

fields.headline: Harvey the cream of local artisans
fields.standfirst: Warwickshire 260 v Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 260 v Gloucestershire
fields.body:
Nothing reflects our social evolution better than Cheltenham. There stands the Gothic chapel, mellow and constant as ever - just like the towering, protective Cotswolds that frame the College ground.

But the spectators have changed. The clerics and the moustachioed military from the officers' mess who once predominated, have virtually gone. Cheltenham has gradually taken on an egalitarian air, with more throaty artisan accents, and more relaxed observers who look like out-of-season lock forwards from the Forest of Dean.

The appreciation, however, does not vary. Those who watch here in annual ritual are as knowledgeable as the supporters who worship at Scarborough's festival shrine. At the moment they are worried about Gloucestershire's wretched championship form.

Cheltenham, historically a loyal ally - whether to sepia spinners like Parker, Cook and Goddard, the bouncing Procter and Walsh, or Hammond's exquisite stroke-making - has now seen the county lose three in a row. They played much better yesterday.

The pundits around the boundary warmed to the way Warwickshire were curbed in the afternoon after they looked capable of building a formidable, if uninspiring, total. In particular they applauded the distinctive perseverance of Ian Harvey, seen by some 12 months ago as an overseas player of modest virtues.

Off his innocuous run-up and pace, Harvey has harnessed his envied skills: late swing, varying wobble and a reluctance to bowl two successive deliveries of vague similarity. He took a championship-best five for 29 in 23 overs.

Warwickshire's batting was at first obdurate; then there were too many bad shots like Neil Smith's and Dougie Brown's. Mark Wagh's half-century was ended with a slip catch. Ashley Giles produced some bold strokes and was upset about his dismissal. David Hemp's batting, over three hours, was his side's best until well caught off a hook to long-leg. At least Ed Giddins scored his first championship run of the season.

The appreciation, however, does not vary. Those who watch here in annual ritual are as knowledgeable as the supporters who worship at Scarborough's festival shrine. At the moment they are worried about Gloucestershire's wretched championship form. Cheltenham, historically a loyal ally - whether to sepia spinners like Parker, Cook and Goddard, the bouncing Procter and Walsh, or Hammond's exquisite stroke-making - has now seen the county lose three in a row. They played much better yesterday. The pundits around the boundary warmed to the way Warwickshire were curbed in the afternoon after they looked capable of building a formidable, if uninspiring, total. In particular they applauded the distinctive perseverance of Ian Harvey, seen by some 12 months ago as an overseas player of modest virtues. Off his innocuous run-up and pace, Harvey has harnessed his envied skills: late swing, varying wobble and a reluctance to bowl two successive deliveries of vague similarity. He took a championship-best five for 29 in 23 overs. Warwickshire's batting was at first obdurate; then there were too many bad shots like Neil Smith's and Dougie Brown's. Mark Wagh's half-century was ended with a slip catch. Ashley Giles produced some bold strokes and was upset about his dismissal. David Hemp's batting, over three hours, was his side's best until well caught off a hook to long-leg. At least Ed Giddins scored his first championship run of the season.

webTitle: Light goes backwards in time

fields.headline: Light goes backwards in time
fields.standfirst: Physicists today claim that they reached 300 times the speed of light. But don't write off Einstein, and don't hold your breath for a                                  time-travelling Star Trek universe, warns Paul Davies
fields.trailText: Physicists today claim that they reached 300 times the speed of light. But don't write off Einstein, and don't hold your breath for a time-travelling Star Trek universe, warns Paul Davies
fields.body:
On the face of it, today's announcement in Nature that a team of Princeton physicists have broken the light barrier demolishes what is arguably science's most cherished principle.

Ever since Albert Einstein formulated his theory of relativity nearly a century ago, it has been a central tenet of physics that nothing can travel faster than light. Now it is claimed that in certain circumstances, light itself can be accelerated up to 300 times its usual speed. But it's too soon to consign the textbooks to the dustbin. As always, the devil is in the detail.

Moving through a vacuum, light travels at 300,000 km per second. According to the theory of relativity, it is the ultimate speed limit for the propagation of any physical influence. That includes spacecraft, subatomic particles, radio signals, or anything that might convey information or cause an effect.

When light passes through a medium such as air, it is slowed. The effect is best explained by analogy with water waves. Try throwing a stone in a pond to make ripples. Focus on a particular wave crest, and it will appear to move fairly fast, but then take a wider perspective to view the group of waves as a whole, and it travels outwards from the point of disturbance noticeably more slowly. It is almost as if the waves are rushing to get nowhere fast. You can watch as new ripples rise up at the back of the wave group, whiz forwards, and fade away at the front.

The same thing happens to light in a medium. It comes about because atoms in the medium create outgoing ripples of light as the primary light wave sweeps by them. When these ripples overlap and combine with the primary wave, they obliterate the parts racing on ahead, suppressing the fast-moving wave front and serving to slow down the group. So light passing through a medium has two associated velocities: that of the group as a whole, and that of the individual wave crests, known as the phase velocity.

A normal medium always reduces the group velocity of light to below its phase velocity, leading to the familiar phenomenon of refraction - the effect that causes a stick to look bent when it is stuck in water. The special feature of the Princeton experiment was the creation of a peculiar state of matter in which this situation is reversed: the secondary ripples of light actually make the wave group travel faster than the phase velocity.

To achieve this odd state of affairs, the scientists used a gas of cold caesium, and then excited the caesium atoms with a laser. So energised, the atoms do more than cause secondary ripples of light, they amplify the light too. It is this amplification that is the key to boosting the speed of the wave group, reportedly to 300 times the speed of light in a vacuum. Bizarrely, the wave distortion achieved is so large, it causes the group velocity to become negative, which means the peak of the wave pulse appears to exit the gas before it enters. In other words, the light waves seem to run backwards.

What makes this result so sensational is the relationship between light speed and causality. The theory of relativity predicts that speed slows time. For example, time passes a bit slower in an aircraft than on the ground, an effect that has been verified using atomic clocks. The time warp is small for everyday motion, but grows without limit as the speed of light is approached. Cosmic rays, for example, travel exceedingly close to the speed of light, and their internal clocks are slowed millions of times.

Relativity theory predicts that if a particle could exceed the speed of light, the time warp would become negative, and the particle could then travel backwards in time.

As Dr Who fans are aware, travel into the past opens up a nest of paradoxes. For example, suppose a faster-than-light particle is used as a signal to explode a bomb in the very lab that the particle itself is created. If the bomb explodes yesterday, the particle cannot be made today. So the bomb won't explode, and the particle will be made.

Either way, you get contradictory nonsense. At stake, then, is the very rationality and causal order of the universe. Allow faster-than-light travel, and the physical world turns into a madhouse .

Timing the speed of a pulse of light is fraught with complications, not least because the shape of the pulse changes when it passes through a medium. To make a pulse of a short duration, it is necessary to mix together waves of many different frequencies, and in a medium each wave will propagate differently.

As for transmitting information, opinions differ about how to associate it with a pulse that has a complicated, changing shape. The inherent fuzziness in a light pulse made up of many different waves superimposed precludes a clean definition of how fast actual information travels.

The problem is closely related to the quantum nature of light, where each frequency component can be thought of as made up of pho tons that behave in some ways like particles. But photons are subject to Heisenberg's principle, according to which there is an inherent uncertainty in their whereabouts. In the pulses of light used in the experiment, it isn't possible to pick out a given component photon and observe it travelling at superluminal velocity.

The Princeton physicists believe this fundamental fuzziness associated with a finite pulse of waves prevents information from exceeding the speed of light, so in an operational sense the light barrier remains unbroken and the causal order of the cosmos is still safe. It is intriguing to see how the wave nature of light rescues the theory of relativity from paradox.

 Paul Davies is visiting professor of physics at Imperial College London, and author of About Time. He will lecture on time travel at the Royal Society on September 21.

webTitle: The best bath scene: Mission Impossible 2

fields.headline: The best bath scene: Mission Impossible 2
fields.trailText: Night. An impossibly glamorous diplomatic party. In the master bedroom, Nyah Nordolf-Hall (Thandie Newton) pulls out a make-up case. It starts to emit a series of high-pitched beeps. She moves to a sunken bath in the corner of the room; the beeps get faster. Delving into her case, she produces a series of picks. Finding a slot in the wall beside the bath, she picks its lock - a range of compartments spring out before her.
fields.body:
Night. An impossibly glamorous diplomatic party. In the master bedroom, Nyah Nordolf-Hall (Thandie Newton) pulls out a make-up case. It starts to emit a series of high-pitched beeps. She moves to a sunken bath in the corner of the room; the beeps get faster. Delving into her case, she produces a series of picks. Finding a slot in the wall beside the bath, she picks its lock - a range of compartments spring out before her.

She looks puzzled, uncertain what to do next.

"I see you've found it."

She spins around to see Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) sitting on the edge of the bath.

"What are you doing here?"

Hunt smirks.

"Think you're the only one who can pick a lock?"

Nyah scowls.

"So, not just a pretty face after all."

Without warning, the host of the party enters. Instinctively, Nyah slides into the bath out of view, pulling Hunt on top of her. Their faces barely an inch apart, Nyah whispers to Hunt.

"Do you mind if I'm on top?"

"No. Either way works for me."

They twist until Nyah is on top.

The host leaves the room again, carrying glasses and a bottle of champagne.

See also: The Man Who Fell To Earth, Gummo, Carry On Matron, Spartacus, The Doors

Don't see also: Sliver

Pointless trivia: Born in Zambia, Thandie Newton spent her childhood living with her family on the coast of Cornwall.

webTitle: West Indies' consolation should not worry England

fields.headline: West Indies' consolation should not worry England
fields.trailText: England looked to be cruising it when West Indies were 139 for 7, but Franklyn Rose's tailend runs, which seemed only to be making a decent match of it, actually did much more than that. They set up only the second close game of the nine qualifiers - and England, perhaps a little blasé, managed to blow it right at the end.
fields.body:
England looked to be cruising it when West Indies were 139 for 7, but Franklyn Rose's tailend runs, which seemed only to be making a decent match of it, actually did much more than that. They set up only the second close game of the nine qualifiers - and England, perhaps a little blasé, managed to blow it right at the end.

There wasn't much wrong with England's bowling. Their seasoned fast men shared all the wickets (apart from a run-out), although they didn't bowl quite as straight as four bowleds might suggest - all four managed to deflect the ball into the stumps somehow.

Perhaps the ash - or whatever it is they make those chunky black stumps out of - has a magnetic attraction for white leather. The West Indians must have thought they'd upset someone: Campbell played on via his elbow, Sarwan used the back of his bat after his Laraesque full followthrough, while Powell and Adams got more routine inside-edges. Even Hick joined the played-on club later - first ball, making three dismissals from his last four balls faced, hardly the sort of preparation he'd have liked for the final.

Mullally, looking down from the lofty heights of 6ft 5ins and second place on the PricewaterhouseCoopers one-day bowling ratings, was England's most economical bowler - but the surprise packet was White, with three wickets and a consistently high reading on the Speedster. Suddenly he's looking like the genuine article with bat and ball, in one-day cricket at least, and those cracks about him being selected because Ray Illingworth owed him money are looking decidedly old hat.

The only quick bowler who didn't manage a wicket was Paul Franks. He looked a little nervous on his England debut, and struggled with his rhythm. There were five no-balls in his two spells - one sequence went no-ball, four-ball, no-ball - and overall he went for more than five an over. Franks did cheer up the home fans with a catch, though: England's new No. 79 (he chose his shirt number to reflect the year of his birth) caught West Indies' No. 99 (Franklyn Rose's favourite ice-cream?).

England's batting was less impressive. Trescothick looked good before his footwork let him down, and after a mid-innings muddle it was left to Stewart once again. He passed 50 for the third time in successive one-day innings - a first for him - after his previous six knocks had amounted to only 50 runs between them. His second hundred in three days was a superb effort, and that short-lived experiment with Chris Read in South Africa (well, at least it gave Stewie a month's holiday) now seems a long way off, and a long way wide of the mark. Few would now bet against Stewart keeping on keeping (and batting, and cheerleading) until the next World Cup, even if he will be pushing 40 by then.

In the end Stewart was left with too much to do, as the rest of a batting order which theoretically stretched down to Franks at No. 9 managed to scratch together only 72 runs between them.

West Indies bounced back after four defeats and a no-result from their other matches. But it was a consolation prize, not much more, as England already had half an eye on Saturday's final against Zimbabwe. However, it will cheer Jimmy Adams and his men up as they contemplate the rest of the Test series. And Test cricket's a different game - it has Ambrose and Walsh in it, for a start.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly
