webTitle: A spot of rain on the way

fields.headline: A spot of rain on the way
fields.standfirst: The satellite pictures are great but those forecasters would never make it on the BBC. Bill Giles casts his expert eye over The Perfect Storm
fields.trailText: The satellite pictures are great but those forecasters would never make it on the BBC. Bill Giles casts his expert eye over The Perfect Storm.
fields.body:
The Perfect Storm was the wrong title for this film. Perhaps it should have been called The Storm of the Century.

"Perfect" is the wrong word to use for something that destroys a fishing trawler and causes human tragedy. It might have been perfect from a meteorologist's point of view but in fact it was more of a disaster.

Still, the movie is a rattling good yarn and a great adventure, packed with noise and action in the mould of a James Bond film. I'm sure it will be a great success with filmgoers this side of the Atlantic, but perhaps not as much as in the US. Nevertheless, the sets and special effects were magnificent. It's a bit slow to get going but is still a great action film and I would recommend it to anyone who wants an evening away from the humdrum of normal life and who doesn't always want a predictable ending.

The Perfect Storm is the story of a fishing boat getting caught up in a developing hurricane some nine years ago. Although at the beginning of the film we are told it is based on a true story, I think it is done so very loosely and contains a great deal of poetic licence. It gets very dramatic during the storm but the truth is nobody knows what the hell it was actually like because the fishermen lost all radio contact.

Even though the forecasting of severe storms has made enormous strides over the past decade, I do feel that the skipper of the fishing boat brought most of the disasters upon himself by not getting or heeding the weather forecast, so he could well be found negligent. I'd probably say the same about the captain of the helicopter rescue crew, since the helicopter scenes, although traumatic and exciting, were far removed from reality.

I thought the actor who played the weatherman was lightweight. The forecaster didn't get as excited as most broadcasting weather forecasters would do if they saw this once-in-100-years storm coming along. He just sat there. For most of us, our eyes would of have gone glazed and we would have got up and started screaming "I want more time" before broadcasting. We would have made much more of it rather than saying blandly: "If this happens and this happens then it could really be something dramatic."

I thought the satellite pictures were great, but of course we've got some wonderful pictures of hurricanes now, and the eye of the storm looked really, really good. I think the sea special effects were also pretty good - suitably horrendous. Whether you get 100ft waves or not in real life, I'm not entirely sure, but it certainly looked good.

I thought the helicopter crew that ran out of fuel but didn't go back to the coast were a bit stupid. Then they jumped into the water - into wild seas - which was ridiculous because you could never find anybody in that, but somehow they managed to locate each other, which was a bit far-fetched. And they talked to each other over screaming, 200-mile-an-hour winds, which is also pretty incredible because you'd never hear anything over that.

George Clooney was very good, but I thought his character was foolish in not taking any weather advice. And when he did eventually get it through his fax he didn't heed it, so he could certainly be blamed for what happened. Having said that, he did have some terrible decisions to make: for the first time in umpteen trips they had a full load of fish and were thinking they were all going to be rich, but they had to go back quickly because the ice machine had gone up the chute. It was then they decided to go straight through this hurricane, which was immensely stupid, but a very tough decision to have to make, I suppose.

When you get hurricanes you can't go very far wrong with the weather forecast. In 1987, when we got it wrong it wasn't a hurricane but hurricane-force winds, which is something different. A hurricane is a tropical revolving storm which you can see clearly on the satellite pictures and it doesn't move very quickly. What we had moved at 60mph. You wouldn't miss a big tropical revolving storm like the one in the film.

 More about The Perfect Storm

webTitle: Portal combat for English learners

fields.headline: Portal combat for English learners
fields.standfirst: David Eastment assesses the growth of Web-based ELT as sites vie for students
fields.trailText: David Eastment assesses the growth of Web-based ELT as sites vie for students.
fields.body:
Learning on the internet is becoming big business. John Chambers, CEO of Cisco Systems, calls it the "second wave" of e-commerce. "E-learning is going to be so big it will make e-mail look like a rounding error," he has said, while International Data Corporation believes that online education will be a $15bn market by 2002. ELT will have a share in this market. The number of users who access the Web in a language other than English is growing fast - more than 100m, according to a recent survey by the internet marketing company Global Reach, and a significant proportion of these users will want to improve their English.

ELT entrepreneurs have not been slow in responding to the challenge: there are hundreds of English language sites now on the Web offering courses, resources, games, newsletters and services such as teacher recruitment. Some, such as International House's Net Languages and the recently-launched BellEnglish. com are backed by big school chains. Others, such as the British Council's new LearnEnglish site acts as a "portal" or gateway to its own and other providers' language resources.

However, the problem with portals is that they are not "sticky". They attract plenty of visits, but the visitors leave as soon as they find what they are looking for. LearnEnglish has some excellent content, but not enough to keep visitors engaged for long periods. One way round this is to create so-called "vortals", or "vertical portals". These are still doorways into material, but all the material is on the same site. Vortals are subject-specific. They want their visitors to stick around.

The dominant vortals in the emerging ELT dotcom sector are Englishtown and GlobalEnglish. Their resourcing dwarfs the competition: GlobalEnglish employs 30 full-time teachers and an additional 20 materials writers; Englishtown has a staff of 120, about half of whom are teachers and writers.

Englishtown, an independent subsidiary of EF Education, was set up in 1997 and now claims to have 500,000 members in more than 100 countries. Online courses are free, but students pay for teacher-led courses.

GlobalEnglish was founded in 1997 by a group of technologists and academics. Like Englishtown, it offers a full range of services, including 24-hour, teacher-led chatrooms and computer-adaptive assessment tests. GlobalEnglish has also recruited an impressive advisory board that includes David Nunan, former TESOL president (see below) and Dave Sperling of the pioneering site ESL Cafe.

At the moment these sites present little threat to conventional schools. There are some good courses on offer, but they are good precisely because they involve a human teacher and teacher-class interaction. Remove the human element and the sites lose much of their value. The electronic "Personal Tutor" on GlobalEnglish is slickly implemented, but makes its recommendations on the basis of three multiple choice questions. Englishtown's publicity claim that "We have everything your local language school offers and more!" is certainly an exaggeration.

Few of the dotcoms are making a good return on investment. Most have business models that anticipate losses for several years while they build up their user base. However, the corporate sector is attractive. Englishtown's main revenue component is in the business-to-business (B2B) sector, where they offer bulk discounts and customised learning programmes. But little is yet available for Young Learners, and sites offering ESP are few and far between, and modestly funded. Meanwhile intense competition is driving prices down - a course on GlobalEnglish costs as little as $20.

The next two years will be challenging for the new providers. They need large numbers of users, but internet access will remain both slow and expensive in many key markets. Competition will continue to keep prices low, while the need to provide interaction with human teachers, whether by email or live videoconferencing, will push costs up.

And staying ahead of the competition will be a headache. In the world of bricks and mortar it might take months before your competitors pick up on an innovation in teaching or an improvement in service level. In the world of clicks innovations can be spotted instantly, and emulated in a few days. The "features battle" is unwinnable. The successful sites will be those that offer the best content and the best teaching, not those with the most features.

 David Eastment is the author of The Internet And ELT (OUP)
fields.bodyText: Learning on the internet is becoming big business. John Chambers, CEO of Cisco Systems, calls it the "second wave" of e-commerce. "E-learning is going to be so big it will make e-mail look like a rounding error," he has said, while International Data Corporation believes that online education will be a $15bn market by 2002. ELT will have a share in this market. The number of users who access the Web in a language other than English is growing fast - more than 100m, according to a recent survey by the internet marketing company Global Reach, and a significant proportion of these users will want to improve their English. ELT entrepreneurs have not been slow in responding to the challenge: there are hundreds of English language sites now on the Web offering courses, resources, games, newsletters and services such as teacher recruitment. Some, such as International House's Net Languages and the recently-launched BellEnglish. com are backed by big school chains. Others, such as the British Council's new LearnEnglish site acts as a "portal" or gateway to its own and other providers' language resources. webTitle: Why the Web is friend not foe

fields.headline: Why the Web is friend not foe
fields.trailText: David Nunan rounds up the reasons why the internet is an invaluable tool in the classroom.
fields.body:
Web-based ELT is extremely flexible, allowing anytime, anywhere learning. This is invaluable for busy professionals who do not have the luxury of a set time for face-to-face instruction. It also offers a supplement to classroom instruction for those learners who can attend regular classes. The computer is a patient tutor, providing the many hours of repetitive skills practice.

Another benefit of internet-based learning resources is the potential for personalisation. Until now one-to-one learning has been largely restricted to expensive, private institutions. Through the internet, however, teachers are able to create modularised programmes to suit individual learner's needs. The best learning sites support all levels of learners, and support self-paced learning in ways that are not always possible in classrooms.

At this stage the ELT dotcoms that have emerged in the last couple of years have both replaced and enhanced classroom-based instruction. The good news for teachers who are fearful that they may be made redundant by new technological means of instruction is that the best sites, and indeed learners themselves, see the teacher as the crucial element in effective learning.

It is true that teaching through the internet demands new skills, but then that's the reality in most professions today. Such skills include managing interactions online to maximise learning opportunities, creating a cohesive learning community among students who may be spread around the globe, and encouraging active learning. In fact there are techniques that can be deployed to simulate experiential, student-centred approaches that are in keeping with communicative approaches to language teaching. However, these demand a certain amount of pedagogical "retooling" on the part of teachers.

From the perspective of the learner the greatest frustrations come with slow connection times in real-time chat and classroom sessions. In some countries, the cost of connecting is also considerable. Despite the disadvantages, however, the Web holds tremendous promise as a medium of instruction. And the potential is not just confined to dedicated language learning sites. There are thousands of sites that provide learners with opportunities to process and produce spoken and written language.

 Dr David Nunan is director and chair of applied linguistics at The University of Hong Kong, and was until recently president of Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL). He recently became senior academic adviser for GlobalEnglish.com.

webTitle: Powergen leaks cash card data

fields.headline: Powergen leaks cash card data
fields.trailText: The electricity utility Powergen yesterday advised all its online customers to change their credit and debit card numbers after an error allowed details of thousands of customers to be accessed by an unauthorised person.
fields.body:
The electricity utility Powergen yesterday advised all its online customers to change their credit and debit card numbers after an error allowed details of thousands of customers to be accessed by an unauthorised person.

Powergen was alerted 10 days ago when a customer, John Chamberlain, accessed the site to pay his bill online.

Mr Chamberlain, an IT manager from Leicester, said he was surprised to discover three files on the web server containing the names, addresses and card details of home and business customers, including his own.

He told the BBC Panorama website: "In under three minutes I had access to 5,000 credit card details. I can't believe how easy it was - I teach this and anyone could have got this information."

A Powergen spokeswoman said a technical error occurred 10 days ago when data was being transferred from one server to another. Complete details of up to 7,000 customers who pay online for gas, electricity and telephone had temporarily slipped outside the security gate on the website.

Powergen said it logged Mr Chamberlain's complaint and took immediate action to correct the error.

But the company only informed customers yesterday after Mr Chamberlain took the story to the e-business news site, silicon.com

Powergen yesterday launched a review of website security and said it would give each customer £50 for the inconvenience of the "precautionary measure" of changing bank card numbers.

Mike Wagner, retail managing director, said: "The website was immediately closed down and our systems experts confirmed that this was a one-off incident."

The company has contacted police about how it became possible to access the information.

Mr Chamberlain told silicon.com he did not "hack" into the Powergen file, but played with the URL - the set of characters and punctuation marks that form a website address.

"I simply removed part of the URL and the details were sitting there on an unsecured directory file," he said.

The security breach comes after a survey last week revealed fear of fraud remained a deterrent to e-commerce.

The survey, commissioned by public relations firm Shandwick International, found that one in three internet users would never make online credit card purchases because of the risk of fraud.

Rob Trevelyan, an ethical hacker who tests internet security for Escrow internet consultants, said the Powergen breach showed shoppers still took a huge risk paying with a debit card online.

"This customer data should not have been on the server and if it was it should have been encrypted. It was a total security breach. You did not need to be a hacker to access it. Any 14-year-old could have done it."

webTitle: Prescott lets the trams take the strain

fields.headline: Prescott lets the trams take the strain
fields.standfirst: The transport secretary, John Prescott, today earmarked a substantial chunk of the massive funds announced in Tuesday's spending review to improve urban rail services, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: The transport secretary, John Prescott, today earmarked a substantial chunk of the massive funds announced in Tuesday's spending review to improve urban rail services, writes Julian Glover
fields.body:
Trams are set for a revival across Britain as part of the government's 10-year strategy for transport announced today by John Prescott.

The secretary of state committed himself to constructing 25 new light-rail systems as part of a £180bn programme of investment in transport over the next decade - a programme criticised by London mayor Ken Livingstone.

In a low-key House of Commons statement which contained few surprises but some significant commitments, Mr Prescott set out how he intends to spend the massive increase in transport funding announced by the chancellor in Tuesday's spending review. "Transport is now a growth industry," he told MPs.

Much of the new spending will focus on capital investment - in railway tracks, roads, trams and bus routes - with the aim of cutting congestion from its present levels. Mr Prescott also pledged that road congestion would be lower in 2010 than it is at present.

The big winner from the announcement will be public transport. Of the £179.7 billion package, £56.3 billion will have to come from the private sector. The area most dependent on private money is the railways, where £34.3 billion of private money will be needed. Railways will gain £60bn of investment over a decade - which includes a £7bn modernisation fund - with the aim of increasing passenger numbers by 50%. The secretary of state for the environment, transport and the regions also guaranteed to implement the findings of the inquiry into the Ladbroke Grove incident, saying: "Safety will always be first in my plans."

Urban transport wins £59bn, much of it aimed at improving bus services, which Prescott sees as a speedy way of cutting congestion, and there will be £25bn for London Transport.

Road spending will concentrate on maintenance, with £30bn going to local authorities to cut their repairs backlog. He also announced plans to widen 360 miles of the motorway and trunk road network and to build 100 new bypasses.

The overall plan would "deliver radical improvement for passengers, motorists, business and for all of us as citizens," Mr Prescott said, adding that the measures were "new ideas, new powers, new resources - a new approach for a new century".

Meanwhile, major improvements aimed at easing congestion will have to be delayed because the capital has been "dumped" with the outstanding bill for the Jubilee Line, London mayor Ken Livingstone said today.

The extension to the east London line, a new Wimbledon/Hackney tube line, a new east Thames river crossing, cross rail and improvements of transport to Heathrow Airport to cope with the new terminal five, will have to be deferred because of the £3.2 billion transport budget secured from government today £104 million must pay for outstanding Jubilee Line bills.

"It's bizarre. Did someone in the Treasury forget to pay the bill and were they waiting for the first available sap to pay for it?" Mr Livingstone said at a news conference.

"It is tragic to have come so close and then to hear the Treasury have done a great doo-doo on the Mayor's doorstep."

webTitle: Three Tests in August 2001

fields.headline: Three Tests in August 2001
fields.trailText: England will be playing back-to-back Tests at home next summer, for the first time since 1912.
fields.body:
England will be playing back-to-back Tests at home next summer, for the first time since 1912.

The fourth Test of the 2001 Ashes series, against Australia at Headingley, will start on Thursday Aug 16. And the final match will begin just seven days later, at The Oval.

An ECB spokesman said the idea was to ensure that three Tests would be packed into the prime holiday month of August (the third Ashes Test starts on Aug 2 at Trent Bridge). It also means there will be play scheduled for the Bank Holiday Monday (Aug 27), and that the series won't stretch into September.

In 1912 there wasn't much choice: there were nine Tests that year, in the one and only Triangular Tournament. After a slow start there were actually four Tests in successive weeks - England v Australia at Old Trafford (started July 29), Australia v South Africa at Trent Bridge (Aug 5), England v South Africa at The Oval (Aug 12) and England v Australia at The Oval (Aug 19). England won that rain-affected tournament, but it wasn't considered a success and hasn't been repeated - not at Test level, anyway.

As far as the Australians are concerned, the ECB are in danger of being over-hospitable again. Not only do the Aussies get to familiarise themselves with English conditions by having all the one-dayers before the Tests, but their first international is at Cardiff, where they were based for their World Cup warm-ups last year.

England's Test programme for 2001

v Pakistan Lord's, May 17-21; Old Trafford, May 31-June 4.

v Australia Edgbaston, July 5-9; Lord's, July 19-23; Trent Bridge, August 2-6; Headingley, August 16-20; The Oval, August 23-27.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: School inspectors to be trained on race

fields.headline: School inspectors to be trained on race
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Ofsted, the schools watchdog for England, will begin this autumn to train inspectors to be more aware of race issues.
fields.body:
Ofsted, the schools watchdog for England, will begin this autumn to train inspectors to be more aware of race issues.

Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, yesterday rejected most of a critical report on Ofsted by the commission for racial equality. He said new guidance for school inspectors this year had taken into account recommendations made in the Macpherson report on the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

"Our new framework, which the CRE have largely ignored, is geared up, post-Macpherson, to monitor how effectively schools ensure that pupils from ethnic minority backgrounds achieve their potential," Mr Woodhead said.

The CRE report was based on "slender" research. But he accepted criticism of the old framework and agreed with the CRE that inspectors should receive further training and guidance.

The CRE report, published yesterday but leaked to the Guardian on Monday, said Ofsted was failing to take seriously its responsibilities on race. It made 31 recommendations, including calling on Ofsted to pay for interpreters at pre-inspection meetings where parents do not speak English.

Ofsted should also include comments on racial equality in the section of its inspection reports sent to parents, and race awareness training should be updated.

The authors, Audrey Osler and Marlene Morrison, asked for an interview with Mr Woodhead while researching the report but were told he was "too busy" to see them.

In a letter, Prof Osler told Mr Woodhead that one senior inspector had remarked: "Race equality is not a priority. Our priority is underachieving white boys."

Mr Woodhead replied: "I am, frankly, surprised by the statement allegedly made to you that 'our priority is underachieving white boys'. Our priority is underachievement, full stop."

The CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, accused Mr Woodhead of being in "denial mode".

Prof Osler said yesterday that Ofsted reports sometimes contained "carelessly loose language" that did not reflect the experience of ethnic minority pupils. It should "use language that is useful to the school and to the parents, rather than just cover an issue without any meaning at all".

webTitle: Elbows, Heads and Vocal chords

fields.headline: Elbows, Heads and Vocal chords
fields.trailText: TURNING POINT
fields.body:
TURNING POINT

John Gregory has had a terrible time in the transfer market of late, so the Fiver is well pleased to see him enjoy a bit of luck. No, honest. Gregory finally made an impact in the marketplace today when he secured the signature of Turkish defender Alpay from Fenerbahce for £5.6m. You may remember Alpay: he's the one who would have delivered a punch to the face of Fernando Couto in the Euro 2000 quarter-finals (had the Portuguese defender not already dived out of the way in a successful effort to get him sent off, that is).

Gregory's luck changed when Alpay's expected move to Greek club Olympiakos collapsed at the last minute. The Villa boss mobilised himself quickly and swooped to snap up a 27-year-old player he describes as having "a lot of good qualities". Managers can never complete swift deals like this without boardroom backing, remember, and we're sure Trinity Road stand regulars would want to take this opportunity to doff their caps to their ultra-popular chairman Doug Ellis for all his selfless work. Yes, we're certainly sure of that.

Having finally signed someone, Gregory set about the vultures hovering over Villa Park with renewed confidence. He shooed off Manchester City and their piddling £6m offer for Ugo Ehiogu - "the bid does not match our valuation and has been rejected" - and then swatted Wimbledon, who are buzzing around Paul Merson, like a fly: "I am not surprised that Wimbledon are interested in taking Paul, but I am sure they will also not be surprised that our response is to keep him."

All in all, then, a good day's work - and still no bids for Gareth Southgate. Yippee!

IF YOU WANT TO GET A PLAYER, GET A HAT

Roughly speaking, there are two methods used by the modern manager to determine his prospective summer signings. One is called the "considered" approach, which involves in-depth analysis of a player's performances and how he would fit into your existing line-up. The other is called the "hat" system, and involves pulling names out of a hat. Can you guess which method Middlesbrough boss Bryan Robson prefers?

Yes, after a summer spent chasing the likes of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, Dani, Nicolas Anelka and Zinedine Zidane, the hard-working Boro boss has yanked a picture of Robbie Fowler from his titfer. "Robbie Fowler's not a bad player," Robson said today, responding to reports that he will offer Liverpool £15m for the heterosexual hit-man. "Everybody knows that we've got quite a bit of money to spend and they know I'm after top-drawer players."

Sadly for Robbo, it seems his hat work will be scuppered by an armband, because Gerard Houllier has confirmed that Fowler will start the season as his captain. "Robbie is the vice-captain," Gerard Houllier explained today, "and because of Jamie Redknapp's injury, if Robbie plays he is captain." Whether the introduction of long-term Liverpool target Christian Ziege into the equation would change Houllier's mind or not is another matter, but as Robson is disinclined to part with the German international, he'll probably have to return to the hat. Who's this 7¾? Let's make a bid for him!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It makes me feel physically sick to see other teams parading trophies" - Roy Keane is by no means a nutter.

MORE THAN WORDS

Excuses for failure at international football have come thick and fast over the past few weeks. Although Kelvin Koogan isn't that quick, when you think about it. But few of our own valiant efforts at blame-shirking can match those of the Russian national team. The Russkies, who have failed to qualify for the last two major international tournaments, have claimed today that they're only rubbish because their national anthem hasn't got any words. "We don't want to hang our heads any longer when our country's anthem is played in domestic and international arenas," Spartak Moscow's Russian internationals wrote to their Lon Chaney look-a-like President. "This is the best way to lose a match before it even starts - we want to sing our national anthem but we are not given the opportunity." Which is not strictly true seeing as, since the break up of the Soviet Union, Russians don't actually have a national anthem to sing.

Arsenal and Aston Villa are both under suspicion of being the mystery side who, according to reports in the Portuguese press, are set to hijack Nuno Gomes's transfer from Benfica to Fiorentina.

Manchester United are believed to have rejected a second attempt by AC Milan to sign David Beckham.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leeds and Rangers have both been confirmed by Uefa as seeded teams in the draw for tomorrow's Big Cup third qualifying round. This means they not only avoid each other but also Internazionale, AC Milan, Valencia, Feyenoord and Lyon.

Reports in French newspaper Le Parisien suggest that Lonely Nicolas Anelka is on the verge of returning to Paris St Germain in a £22m deal. PSG president Laurent Perpere and Anelka's representative, his brother Didier Anelka, sealed the deal in Madrid during a meeting with new Real president Florentino Perez, the paper claims.

Everton have been told that if they are to build a 55,000 seater stadium they will have to leave Goodison Park. A report on the redevelopment of their current ground suggests that merely increasing Goodison's capacity to 45,000 would cost upwards of £50m, take several years, and cause local problems.

Meanwhile, German club FC Hamburg have confirmed that Everton are to sign Danish international midfielder Thomas Gravesen. "I couldn't let such a good opportunity slip away," said Gravesen, who was a member of Denmark's Euro 2000 squad.

Manchester United defender Ronny Johnsen should be fit for the start of the new season. He is believed to have finally recovered from a condition called jumper's knee which kept him out of the United team for the whole of last season.

Muzzy Izzett has signed a new four-year contract with Leicester, putting an end to speculation that he was set to leave the club.

Izzett's teammate Neil Lennon has been the subject of a £6m bid from Martin O'Neill's Celtic, and will talk with manager Peter Taylor about his future tomorrow.

Rangers have given FC Schalke 04 until the end of the day to accept or reject their £6.5m offer for Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. "It will be sorted out way or another today. The manager has said that if we don't resolve it today, we must move on," chairman David Murray said.

Everton's new signing, Ghanaian midfielder Alex Nyarko, has been awarded a work permit by the department of employment.

St Johnstone have signed French defender Mohamed Sylla on a three-year deal.

webTitle: M&S investors attack everything from pay to pockets

fields.headline: M&S investors attack everything from pay to pockets
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's new chairman, Luc Vandevelde, came through his toughest test yet yesterday: a 90-minute grilling by the company's army of blue-rinsed shareholders.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's new chairman, Luc Vandevelde, came through his toughest test yet yesterday: a 90-minute grilling by the company's army of blue-rinsed shareholders.

More than 1,400 squeezed into the Royal Festival Hall with gripes varying from the size of executive pay packages (too large) to the pockets on gentlemen's grey flannel trousers (too small).

Nearly every question was hostile; looking at the company's 13-strong board, one investor asked whether they were gathered for the "last supper".

Furious at the group's disastrous recent performance, another declared he was "a very bitter man", saying: "I'm on the verge of going to a cancer shop, giving them all my clothes and never going back to M&S."

There was little respite in the latest trading news: M&S's like-for-like sales rose just 0.8% in the 16 weeks to July 15. The group's shares slipped 3p to 232.75p, not far from their all-time low of 220p.

Mr Vandevelde and his colleagues were accused of "sitting in ivory towers in Baker Street looking at balance sheets rather than finding out what customers want".

There was a backlash against the group's efforts to tempt younger customers. One elderly investor said: "You have abandoned your loyal mature customers. You seem to feel people like us are well past our sell-by dates."

Another complained that M&S clothes appeared to be tailored for slim figures: "You have no idea how many people in this country are overweight and are not beautiful."

Some of the strongest bile was directed at executive pay. Investors complained that many directors received increases last year despite cutting the dividend payout. One told the chairman: "They should be taking a similar drop to us. You mention that they are all experienced people, but they have failed."

Another called for the departure of all the non-executive directors: "Their prime function is to protect the interests of shareholders. They've singularly failed. Is there a chance that they will resign gracefully?"

Mr Vandevelde defended the group's remuneration committee, which is headed by the former MI5 chief Dame Stella Rimington. He said nine directors had left the group in the past two years: "Those remaining have my confidence and I want to ensure that they are paid competitively."

Mr Vandevelde said it would take years to turn the group around. Among those to suffer will be charities: M&S will "substantially reduce" the £14.1m it donated to good causes last year.

webTitle: Analysis: John Prescott puts transport policy back on the rails

fields.headline: Transport policy back on the rails
fields.standfirst: John Prescott's ambitious 10-year national plan will do much to reverse voter perception that Labour is weak on transport, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt
fields.trailText: John Prescott's ambitious 10-year national plan will do much to reverse voter perception that Labour is weak on transport, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
John Prescott demonstrated today that Labour has finally woken up to Britain's transport crisis, which poses one of the strongest threats to the future of the government.

His 10-year national plan, which will see a 20% increase in funding for railways and roads, will go a long way to reversing the perception among many voters that transport is one of Labour's weakest areas.

Hailing his plan as a "new approach for a new century", the deputy prime minister promised radical improvements for passengers and motorists. His dramatic rhetoric has, for once, matched the huge sums unveiled in the commons, with £60bn for railways and £59bn for roads.

The injection of cash, which follows months of haggling with the treasury, will calm the nerves of Labour MPs who fear that growing public anger over Britain's crumbling transport infrastructure could cost them dear at the next election. Many MPs believe that the government has acted at the eleventh hour after ministers seriously miscalculated Labour's transport policy after the 1997 election.

Transport was one of the government's weakest areas for the first two years of this parliament for two reasons. Downing Street initially failed to take the issue seriously, as signalled by the appointment of the ineffective Gavin Strang as the first transport minister.

Dr Strang was sidelined by Mr Prescott, his boss at the transport department, whose fraught relations with Downing Street set back progress on transport by years. Mr Prescott suffered a severe embarrassment in 1998 when his plans to introduce congestion charges were vetoed by Downing Street. The move prompted him to brand the Downing Street policy unit as "teeny boppers".

Government inertia over transport was exploited by the Tories, whose private polling alerted them within months of the 1997 general election to public alarm over the issue. Tony Blair finally responded last summer by appointing the former Scottish media mogul, Lord Macdonald, as his fifth transport minister.

Bernard Jenkin, Lord Macdonald's shadow, this afternoon dismissed the transport plan as "fantasy land spending", highlighting Tory irritation that Labour has regained the initiative.

His frustration provides a strong example of how a looming policy disaster for the government can be turned round when Downing Street provides a lead. Only time will tell whether the action on transport has come too late for the government.

webTitle: Why the peace talks failed

fields.headline: Why the peace talks failed
fields.standfirst: After nine days of negotiations with the Palestinians, Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak announced he had had enough and was going home. Former Guardian Jerusalem correspondent Derek Brown examines the stumbling blocks to peace in the Middle East
fields.trailText: After nine days of negotiations with the Palestinians, Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak announced he had had enough and was going home. Former Guardian Jerusalem correspondent Derek Brown examines the stumbling blocks to peace in the Middle East
fields.body:
The famous handshake with which Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat sealed their peace accord in the late summer of 1993, was a potent symbol of reconciliation. But it was just that: a symbol. The two leaders were able to stand together on the White House lawn only because their negotiators had skirted or ignored all the really contentious issues.

Seven years on, Israel and the Palestinians are finally confronting those issues. The years between have been littered with broken deadlines and false dawns, eruptions of violence, and passionate mutual recrimination.

Last night the Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak announced that after nine days of eyeball-to-eyeball negotiations, he'd had enough and was going home. Ninety minutes later, a haggard Bill Clinton said that Barak and Arafat and their teams would after all stay on in Camp David, outside Washington, and resume their attempt to batter down the remaining barriers to peace.

Those barriers remain as dauntingly high as they were seven years ago.

Jerusalem
The biggest, most visceral issue of all. Most Israelis insist that the city, which they captured and annexed in 1967, must remain their perpetual capital. The Palestinians are equally adamant that east Jerusalem, including the Old City, must be the capital of their new state. There has been little hint of compromise, though Arafat aides are now hinting that there is a US compromise proposal for joint sovereignty. Barak knows that if he even discusses such an idea he will probably be committing political suicide, but there are intriguing suggestions in the Israeli papers that the Palestinians could be given authority over the Arab sections of the city, and install their capital in Abu Dis, an eastern suburb.

Israeli settlements
More than 150,000 Jewish colonists now live in fortified settlements on the West Bank, which they call Judea and Samaria. Many of the settlers are religiously inspired, believing they have a duty to reclaim the historic land of Israel. They live among 2m Palestinians, most of whom live under the ramshackle rule of the Palestinian National Authority (Israelis refuse to use the word 'National') headed by Yasser Arafat. The settlers, backed by the Israeli right, insist they will stay. The Palestinians say they must leave. In recent days there has been talk of mass action to overwhelm the settlements and send their occupants packing. The Israeli Defence Forces have been placed on a high state of alert to protect the settlements.

Border demarcation
The original peace accord, secretly negotiated in Oslo, implicitly assigned the West Bank and the Gaza Strip to the Palestinians, but was deliberately vague about final borders. The Palestinians want all the territory captured by Israel in the Six Day War of 1967 to be returned. Israel has refused to countenance a total withdrawal. It wants to retain a security presence in the Jordan Valley and access corridors to any remaining settlements. It also insists that Greater Jerusalem, which includes a sizeable chunk of the West Bank, will remain under the Star of David.

Final status of Palestine
Yasser Arafat has repeatedly pledged to establish a sovereign state, with or without Israeli approval. At present he has little more than municipal authority over the Gaza Strip and parts of the West Bank. The PLO leader greatly enjoys the trappings of state, and has his own troops and police, but they are utterly ill-equipped to confront, let alone take on, Israel's formidable army. Arafat is also handicapped by the lukewarm support of his Arab neighbours for a sovereign state. They fear that an independent Palestine would claim the allegiance of their sizeable populations of Palestinian refugees.

Refugees
There are some 6m Palestinian refugees scattered through the Middle East and further afield, notably in the United States. The Palestinian diaspora dates back to the vicious war of 1947-48, when the embryonic state of Israel was attacked by its Arab neighbours. Many Israelis believe that the old British mandate territory of Palestine is now theirs by conquest and by historical destiny, and that the Arabs should stay where they are. The Palestinians argue that they have rather more right to their ancestral lands than the waves of Jewish immigrants from around the world.

webTitle: How peace became American pie in the sky

fields.headline: How peace became American pie in the sky
fields.standfirst: The failure to broker a peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians at Camp David was born out of Clinton's arrogance, writes Middle Eastern editor Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: The failure to broker a peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians at Camp David was born out of Clinton's arrogance, writes Middle Eastern editor Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
"God, it's hard!" Bill Clinton said, sounding as if someone had just asked him to multiply 242 by 338 in his head. Well, nobody suggested it would be easy.

But Clinton had set great store by what cynics describe as his "legacy project" - earning a place in history as the man who finally brought peace to the Middle East. By summoning the Israelis and Palestinians to Camp David, he deliberately invited comparisons with the meeting 22 years ago when his Democratic predecessor, Jimmy Carter, brokered peace between Israel and Egypt.

Yesterday's outcome may well enhance history's assessment of Carter (who was thrown out of office after a single term) but it can only diminish the stature of Clinton. Clinton's two big Middle East initiatives this year - the Geneva summit with the late President Assad of Syria last spring, and now Camp David - have both flopped. He will, no doubt, claim the credit for trying and pin the blame on intractable differences between the protagonists. But in both cases there is a common factor behind the failures: American arrogance.

All the issues were well-known, the arguments well-rehearsed, long before the meetings. It has been obvious for years that Jerusalem is a major sticking point. So why did Clinton call the summit? Was it because he had something up his sleeve that he believed would turn Camp David into the brilliant success that he craved? Ernot exactly.

In a similar vein to Geneva last spring, Clinton seems to have assumed that congenial surroundings, and the presence of the world's most powerful man, would somehow work magic. Once at the summit, Assad and Arafat would turn to jelly, abandoning principles which they clearly regarded as important (even if Clinton didn't).

Having done little to secure their confidence as an honest broker, having failed to come up with a workable plan to bridge the gaps, Clinton simply presented them with a thinly disguised version of Israeli proposals.

Nobody, except perhaps Bill Clinton, should be surprised at the result.

He will, no doubt, claim the credit for trying and pin the blame on intractable differences between the protagonists. But in both cases there is a common factor behind the failures: American arrogance. All the issues were well-known, the arguments well-rehearsed, long before the meetings. It has been obvious for years that Jerusalem is a major sticking point. So why did Clinton call the summit? Was it because he had something up his sleeve that he believed would turn Camp David into the brilliant success that he craved? Ernot exactly. In a similar vein to Geneva last spring, Clinton seems to have assumed that congenial surroundings, and the presence of the world's most powerful man, would somehow work magic. Once at the summit, Assad and Arafat would turn to jelly, abandoning principles which they clearly regarded as important (even if Clinton didn't). Having done little to secure their confidence as an honest broker, having failed to come up with a workable plan to bridge the gaps, Clinton simply presented them with a thinly disguised version of Israeli proposals. Nobody, except perhaps Bill Clinton, should be surprised at the result.

webTitle: Cybershopping

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Summer holidays.
fields.body:
Summer holidays

It doesn't matter how far in advance you book your holiday, there's always going to be something you need at the last minute. Rather than spending your lunch hours in a flap, relax with a little online shopping.

If you've spent all your cash on the holiday, head to www.accessorize.co.uk for the basics. You won't win any prizes on the beach for the most original accessories, but you can click your way quickly and cheaply to the essential flip flops (£5.99), sarong (£14.99) and shades (£9.99). If you're after something a little more exclusive, try www.thecrosscatalogue.com. Yes, you will end up paying five times as much for your flip-flops, but hey, with a blue delphinium or pink cosmos flower on top, they're worth it.

Sadly, you've missed out on the Malatesta Indian sarong for this year, but you can still get the pink/red lotus flower sarong (£38) and the Dosa Palm Basket (£19) which is just big enough for your beach towel, book and sunblock. For a stylish solution to the men- in- sandals problem, go to www.brownsfashion.com and pick up a pair of Prada Sport slide flip-flops in black or grey (£125).

Looking for a bikini? Go to www.intofashion.co.uk and you're guaranteed to find something different. The Gharani Strok cotton bikini (£96) isstylish in pink or blue paisley.

But all the bits and bobs in the world won't make any difference if your skin looks bad. Health and beauty store www.nutravida.com have summer packs of vitamins and natural beauty products to keep you looking lovely.

webTitle: How much can you pay for

fields.headline: How much can you pay for
fields.standfirst: ... hair elastics
fields.trailText: ... hair elastics
fields.body:
Do you like putting shiny slides and grips and all kinds of sparkly things in your hair? The style-conscious who shop at Louis Vuitton clearly do, as their funky hair elastics - or ponytail bands - have been proving.

The bands from Vuitton's ready-to-wear range have been flying out of the shops since they appeared on the catwalk. In fact so popular are these fab little blocks of Perspex that there are waiting lists.

Red is best if you want something bright to match your Chanel lippy and nail varnish, but the Vuitton devotee will be torn between the mocha and the beige. A pack of two - well if you're really going for the retro, little girl look, pigtails are best - cost £40; an absolute bargain if you think of all the satisfaction logo addicts will derive from a truly understated designer purchase.

And if anybody asks why you've got a pair of dice in your hair just remember that style is wasted on some people.

Stockist details: 020-7235 3356.

webTitle: Cheque, cash or card?

fields.headline: Cheque, cash or card?
fields.standfirst: As the summer holidays get into full swing,  Liz Stuart  looks at the best way of taking - and spending - your money abroad
fields.trailText: As the summer holidays get into full swing, Liz Stuart looks at the best way of taking - and spending - your money abroad.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank this week stands accused of overcharging customers for exchanging currencies abroad. The European Commission has found that British tourists holidaying in Europe are paying over the odds when buying their local currency, and Barclays' Portuguese arm has been named and shamed.

So where should you buy your holiday money for the best in value and convenience? Is buying before you fly the better option? And in what form should you take it?

Some people dash to the bureau de change in the airport, anxiously scanning the flight board while they decide just how much they will need for two weeks in Riga. Other more organised types buy months in advance, speculating that the value of the euro will continue to rise. But most people, according to Thomas Cook, buy their cash eight days before departure.

The pound's strength against the euro peaked in May, but it is still 3% stronger against European currencies than it was last year, meaning that buying £500 worth of currency would give you an additional £15 in euros. The pound's increase against the drachma means you get £35 more than last year when exchanging £500, and its leap against the Turkish lira means you would get £195 more this year than last when changing the same £500, although local inflation will effectively cancel this out. Travellers to the United States will lose out, however; the dollar has risen 4% and buyers of £500 of dollars will get £20 less.

Although it makes sense to have some liquid local cash when arriving in a country, using your credit or debit card abroad is the cheapest way to pay. This could either be at the point of sale or by using the cards to withdraw money from an ATM. Using a card means you do not have to carry wads of cash or travellers cheques with you, athough there is still an element of risk involved as the card itself could be stolen. Bear in mind also that your remote Greek island may not have a cash machine.

The banks charge differing rates for using cards abroad. Royal Bank of Scotland, for instance, charges 2% of the sterling equivalent of what you withdraw, to a maximum of £4 and an exchange rate charge of 2.65% for withdrawing with a debit card. Credit card issuers charge around 1.5% to withdraw cash at an ATM, and some may charge a daily interest rate if the account is not settled in full when the bill is received. Nationwide has the cheapest credit and debit cards and Co-operative Bank the most expensive.

According to the Consumers Association, making a purchase of 1,000 French francs with a credit or debit card costs, on average, £97, compared with £99 to buy the same amount of currency in the UK.

Next in order of expense are travellers cheques. Whether you buy sterling cheques or foreign currency ones will probably depend on where you are going. In the US dollar cheques can be used in the same way as cash, and so small denominations are advisable. The same applies to Germany and the more touristy regions of Spain. But if you do buy in the local currency you can usually avoid paying commission when cashing them in. Either way, all Thomas Cook and American Express cash outlets cash their respective cheques for free, regardless of the denomination.

When it comes to buying travellers cheques, Thomas Cook charges 2%, with a minimum charge of £3, while American Express takes just 1% commission. Travelex rates vary according to the branch. Shops at BAA-owned airports charge a minimum of £3 commission on sums up to £167, after which the rate is 1.5%.

Most pricey of all is buying currency before you leave. Travelex charges a minimum of £2.50 to change sums up to £167, after which the rate is 1.5%. Thomas Cook and American Express charge a £2 flat fee for foreign notes, regardless of how much you buy.

Alternatively, you could order your currency over the internet. The Chequepoint, International Currency Exchange, Post Office, Travelex and Thomas Cook sites all have this provision, although high commission charges make this an expensive - if convenient - way of buying. ICE charges £3 commission and £4.95 for delivery, while Thomas Cook's commission rate of £5 includes delivery. Chequepoint and Travelex are both commission-free, however, and do not charge for delivery.

Shopping around for the best exchange rates is not really worth while. On average, bureaux de change are slightly cheaper for foreign currency, but banks are better for buying travellers cheques. From time to time both will have special offers - Thomas Cook, for instance, is selling holiday cash commission free for the next three weeks, starting tomorrow.

When you have to change your foreign currency back to sterling, Thomas Cook and American Express will buy back any unused notes for no commission, provided you present your receipt, although Thomas Cook specifies that you need to have bought at least £100 worth of money in the first place. For £2.50, Travelex airport branches guarantee that they will buy back from you at exactly the rate you bought.

Travellers cheques can also often be bought back commission-free, but you should check the terms of your issuer; Abbey National and HSBC, for instance, only buy back sterling travellers cheques on a no commission basis.

Coins can also be changed. British Airways says that £30m is wasted each year by travellers keeping their francs and pesatas as loose change. Thomas Cook and Amex will both accept pesetas, French francs, US cents and German marks. For other coins try the Travelex machine at the airport, which will be branded either Coinex or Foreign Coin Exchange. Each machine accepts the four currencies most popular in that location, so if you are in Terminal 4 at Heathrow that is French francs, US and Australian dollars and the Dutch guilder. The exchange rate, however, is poor, so why not do a good deed and put your coins into the airline charity envelope?

Cash tips

* If you are going to the United States increase the limit on your credit card. Many hotels and car-hire companies block out credit on your card in lieu of a deposit.

* Do not use a debit card to buy currency or travellers cheques in the UK; you will be charged a handling fee even though the money is coming straight from your account.

* Buy some dual-signature travellers cheques, allowing either of the signatories to countersign them for cash. These can be useful in emergencies.

* French credit and debit cards have security strips rather than magnetic stripes so ATMs may not be able to read your card. Take an alternative means of payment.

* Always take a mixture of payment methods, some cash, some cheques and a credit card for back-up.

webTitle: Full text of Prescott's statement

fields.headline: Full text of Prescott's statement
fields.standfirst:
The full text of John Prescott's statement to the House of Commons on the 10 year plan for transport

Transport 2010 - The 10 Year Plan
fields.trailText: With permission, Madam Speaker, I will make a statement on the Ten Year Plan for Transport.
fields.body:
With permission, Madam Speaker, I will make a statement on the Ten Year Plan for Transport.

Transport is a subject that has been close to my heart for all my working life.

But for decades it has been in decline - dogged by stop-go funding and a short- term approach.

Madam Speaker, on Tuesday the Chancellor set out how we can now begin to invest properly in our public services.

He was able to do that because we have dealt with debt and sorted out the public finances.

This meant we had to stick to the depressed Tory spending figures we inherited.

We continued the last Government's fuel duty escalator both to limit greenhouse gas emissions and restore the public finances.

That wasn't easy.

It wasn't popular.

But it was the right thing to do:

Now we can build and invest for the future.

Decades of under-investment and the lack of strategic planning had left us with a transport system in crisis.

That is already changing. In three years, we have made real improvements:

we have begun to tackle the road maintenance backlog; the overall decline in bus passengers has been halted and in many areas passenger numbers are rising; and rail passengers have increased by 17% and rail freight by 22% since the General Election.

Transport is now a growth industry, and many of the problems it faces are of expansion, not decline.

We have laid the foundations for the long term:

we needed to integrate the Departments of Environment and Transport, we've done that; we needed a new strategy, we've done that; we needed radical new legislation, we've done that; we needed new forms of finance, we've done that; and today I am announcing the new resources to bring about a step-change in transport.

So, Madam Speaker, these are new ideas, new powers, new resources - a new approach for a new century.

It is on these foundations we are building today's 10 Year Programme.

It is based on long-term investment by Government and business to modernise the country's transport system.

It is vital for our economic success, and for the quality of our lives.

It is excellent news for manufacturers and the construction sector who will be able to plan for the long term.

On Tuesday the Chancellor announced that in the next three years, public spending on transport will rise from 5 billion pounds to over 9 billion. Capital investment will double in real terms.

This was widely welcomed.

The AA said it was: "a welcome change from decades of penny-pinching and under-investment.

They also said: "There's no doubt that this represents the most serious attempt to tackle our transport crisis in years".

The Rail Users' Committee said the announcement was: "good news for rail passengers and for the country".

The CBI also welcomed it.

And the CBI Chair, Digby Jones, said on the Today Programme this morning that what is needed is a 10 Year programme providing substantial public and private investment, up to £180 billion.

My Department's modelling, analysis and consultation comes to a similar conclusion. Our analysis is published in a document available in the Library.

There is now a broad consensus about what is needed to reduce congestion, provide a bigger, better and safer railway and real choice in public transport.

With public investment keeping pace with economic growth after 2004, total spending over the 10 years - public and private - will be 180 billion pounds.

132 billion pounds of this - almost three quarters - will come from the public purse.

This is not all new money. But even if we maintained this year's spending as the norm, that means over 50 billion pounds of extra public expenditure.

So, Madam Speaker, capital investment by Government and business together will be 75% more in real terms than over the last decade.

The Plan addresses the issues in a realistic and business-like way. No frills, no promises of a rosy, traffic-free future. Just our best judgements- based on detailed analysis - of what the new resources will deliver.

We are securing long term investment through long term partnership contracts:

new rail franchises lasting up to twenty years, 30-year contracts for roads and 30-year contracts for the London Underground.

But let me make it absolutely clear, if we put in public money we expect rail and bus companies - and local authorities - to deliver the goods: more investment and better services for the travelling public. On budget and on time.

Madam Speaker, the policy we inherited on the railways planned for decline and reduced public support.

Our programme includes 60 billion pounds for a bigger, better, safer railway - the biggest investment in railways for generations.

We will deliver:

better quality for the travelling public, lower regulated fares, 50% more passengers and 80% more rail freight.

- a new Strategic Rail Authority with a new Rail Modernisation Fund of 7 billion pounds to help deliver those goals.

So we will deliver a railway system which is:

better for passengers better for freight better for the economy better for the environment

A good deal all round.

Our programme includes 59 billion pounds for modernising local transport in every region throughout the country.

Increasing bus use by 10%, with guided buses, priority routes, park and ride and a modern fleet. Building on the £400 million of private investment that has already taken place.

Light rail can transform our cities. Manchester and other cities have already shown what a difference it can make. So we are going to provide the resources for up to 25 new projects in our major cities.

We will create greater social justice with:

more accessible buses, trains and taxis for disabled people; cut-price fares for pensioners and disabled people.

And for the first time we are recognising the problems of people who live in poorly-served, deprived urban areas, cut off from jobs and services. They can look to help from a new Urban Bus Challenge Fund to provide new links to their communities.

Our successful Rural Transport Fund, which has already secured 2000 extra services, will rise from 60 million to 95 million pounds a year with a Rural Transport Partnership established in every county.

Both urban and rural communities will benefit from an extension to fuel duty rebate for community transport.

Small-scale, local improvements can make a big difference to people's lives, such as schemes to make walking and cycling safer and easier and 20mph zones, especially where children are most at risk.

We will increase funding for these schemes.

Madam Speaker, in London, our great capital city, we inherited a creaking transport system, congested roads and overcrowded trains.

We have already made major investments in the capital, with the Jubilee Line and Docklands Light Railway Extensions and other projects.

But our programme goes much further.

The Mayor of London asked for 3 billion pounds over the next 3 years. London will receive 3.2 billion pounds.

Over the next 10 years our programme provides 25 billion pounds to support the London Transport strategy, with better buses, less crowded trains and less congestion on the roads.

This will be enough to produce a step change in bus services, town centre improvements and safer walking and cycling.

The Public-Private Partnership will secure investment in the existing Underground.

And we have made provision for new links; an orbital London railway and longer-term projects such as a new east-west rail link and East Thames crossings.

And we are determined to use refranchising to get better, more reliable rail services for commuters.

Madam Speaker, these major improvements in public transport throughout the country will help reduce congestion and pollution.

Sensible land-use planning and new technology can make a difference.

But we also need to make better use of our road network.

We have already set up studies into our busiest transport corridors to find solutions that involve all types of transport.

The first conclusions will emerge over the next few months and are providing the resources to implement the results.

The programme includes 21 billion pounds for the strategic road network. This is enough:

to widen 360 miles of the most congested roads, such as the A1 and M6; to invest in 'electronic motorways' to manage traffic better and to keep drivers informed.

There will be:

100 new bypasses to take traffic out of hard-pressed villages and towns; schemes to tackle congestion and safety hotspots; and low noise surfaces on 60% of the trunk road network, including all concrete roads.

We have already dealt with the backlog of trunk road repairs.

We will enable local authorities to get rid of the backlog on our local roads with a 30 billion pound maintenance programme.

Without the measures in the Plan, congestion is forecast to grow by 28% on inter-urban trunk roads and by 15% in larger urban areas.

With the Plan, we will not only eliminate this forecast growth. We will actually reduce congestion below current levels by 2010.

Our proposals will produce savings in greenhouse gas emissions, helping to achieve our Kyoto targets and more.

We will improve air quality, with new resources to encourage cleaner fuels and vehicles.

Madam Speaker, safety is fundamental to our Plan.

The terrible accidents at Ladbroke Grove and Southall - and over 3000 deaths on our roads every year - are a vivid reminder that we can never afford to be complacent.

We will ensure the installation of train protection systems, as recommended by Sir David Davies.

I have repeatedly stressed that we will not pre-empt Lord Cullen's Inquiry. But I also give a categorical assurance that the Plan will deliver any further measures arising from Lord Cullen's Inquiry.

Safety will always comes first in my priorities.

Our roads are already amongst the safest in Europe. Over the next decade we are determined to reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured in road accidents by 40%, and by 50% for children.

We are providing the resources to enable government, the Highways Agency and local authorities, to play their part in achieving these targets.

Conclusion

It has often been the role of Labour Governments to modernise this country's infrastructure.

That is what we are doing again with our 10 year plan.

Long term investment and public-private partnership to increase choice and cut congestion.

The Opposition have no plans to cut congestion only to cut public spending. The public will ask them to declare where they would make cuts in our programme.

Madam Speaker, this is a Labour Government working with business to deliver the long-term investment needed to rebuild our infrastructure, cut congestion, improve public transport and give people choice.

Modernising the transport system will take time.

New roads and railways aren't built overnight.

But with sustained Government investment and the backing of business we will make year-on-year improvements to get the job done.

This Plan will get Britain moving and give the people of this country a transport system they can rely on.

The British people have waited decades for a long-term approach like this.

It is what the people of Britain deserve and I commend it to the House.

No frills, no promises of a rosy, traffic-free future. Just our best judgements- based on detailed analysis - of what the new resources will deliver. We are securing long term investment through long term partnership contracts: new rail franchises lasting up to twenty years, 30-year contracts for roads and 30-year contracts for the London Underground. But let me make it absolutely clear, if we put in public money we expect rail and bus companies - and local authorities - to deliver the goods: more investment and better services for the travelling public. On budget and on time. Madam Speaker, the policy we inherited on the railways planned for decline and reduced public support. Our programme includes 60 billion pounds for a bigger, better, safer railway - the biggest investment in railways for generations. We will deliver: better quality for the travelling public, lower regulated fares, 50% more passengers and 80% more rail freight. - a new Strategic Rail Authority with a new Rail Modernisation Fund of 7 billion pounds to help deliver those goals. So we will deliver a railway system which is: better for passengers better for freight better for the economy better for the environment A good deal all round. Our programme includes 59 billion pounds for modernising local transport in every region throughout the country. Increasing bus use by 10%, with guided buses, priority routes, park and ride and a modern fleet. Building on the £400 million of private investment that has already taken place. Light rail can transform our cities. Manchester and other cities have already shown what a difference it can make. So we are going to provide the resources for up to 25 new projects in our major cities. We will create greater social justice with: more accessible buses, trains and taxis for disabled people; cut-price fares for pensioners and disabled people. And for the first time we are recognising the problems of people who live in poorly-served, deprived urban areas, cut off from jobs and services. They can look to help from a new Urban Bus Challenge Fund to provide new links to their communities. Our successful Rural Transport Fund, which has already secured 2000 extra services, will rise from 60 million to 95 million pounds a year with a Rural Transport Partnership established in every county. Both urban and rural communities will benefit from an extension to fuel duty rebate for community transport. Small-scale, local improvements can make a big difference to people's lives, such as schemes to make walking and cycling safer and easier and 20mph zones, especially where children are most at risk. We will increase funding for these schemes. Madam Speaker, in London, our great capital city, we inherited a creaking transport system, congested roads and overcrowded trains. We have already made major investments in the capital, with the Jubilee Line and Docklands Light Railway Extensions and other projects. But our programme goes much further. The Mayor of London asked for 3 billion pounds over the next 3 years. London will receive 3.2 billion pounds. Over the next 10 years our programme provides 25 billion pounds to support the London Transport strategy, with better buses, less crowded trains and less congestion on the roads. This will be enough to produce a step change in bus services, town centre improvements and safer walking and cycling. The Public-Private Partnership will secure investment in the existing Underground. And we have made provision for new links; an orbital London railway and longer-term projects such as a new east-west rail link and East Thames crossings. And we are determined to use refranchising to get better, more reliable rail services for commuters. Madam Speaker, these major improvements in public transport throughout the country will help reduce congestion and pollution. Sensible land-use planning and new technology can make a difference. But we also need to make better use of our road network. We have already set up studies into our busiest transport corridors to find solutions that involve all types of transport. The first conclusions will emerge over the next few months and are providing the resources to implement the results. The programme includes 21 billion pounds for the strategic road network. This is enough: to widen 360 miles of the most congested roads, such as the A1 and M6; to invest in 'electronic motorways' to manage traffic better and to keep drivers informed. There will be: 100 new bypasses to take traffic out of hard-pressed villages and towns; schemes to tackle congestion and safety hotspots; and low noise surfaces on 60% of the trunk road network, including all concrete roads. We have already dealt with the backlog of trunk road repairs. We will enable local authorities to get rid of the backlog on our local roads with a 30 billion pound maintenance programme. Without the measures in the Plan, congestion is forecast to grow by 28% on inter-urban trunk roads and by 15% in larger urban areas. With the Plan, we will not only eliminate this forecast growth. We will actually reduce congestion below current levels by 2010. Our proposals will produce savings in greenhouse gas emissions, helping to achieve our Kyoto targets and more. We will improve air quality, with new resources to encourage cleaner fuels and vehicles. Madam Speaker, safety is fundamental to our Plan. The terrible accidents at Ladbroke Grove and Southall - and over 3000 deaths on our roads every year - are a vivid reminder that we can never afford to be complacent. We will ensure the installation of train protection systems, as recommended by Sir David Davies. I have repeatedly stressed that we will not pre-empt Lord Cullen's Inquiry. But I also give a categorical assurance that the Plan will deliver any further measures arising from Lord Cullen's Inquiry. Safety will always comes first in my priorities. Our roads are already amongst the safest in Europe. Over the next decade we are determined to reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured in road accidents by 40%, and by 50% for children. We are providing the resources to enable government, the Highways Agency and local authorities, to play their part in achieving these targets. Conclusion It has often been the role of Labour Governments to modernise this country's infrastructure. That is what we are doing again with our 10 year plan. Long term investment and public-private partnership to increase choice and cut congestion. The Opposition have no plans to cut congestion only to cut public spending. The public will ask them to declare where they would make cuts in our programme. Madam Speaker, this is a Labour Government working with business to deliver the long-term investment needed to rebuild our infrastructure, cut congestion, improve public transport and give people choice. Modernising the transport system will take time. New roads and railways aren't built overnight. But with sustained Government investment and the backing of business we will make year-on-year improvements to get the job done. This Plan will get Britain moving and give the people of this country a transport system they can rely on. The British people have waited decades for a long-term approach like this. It is what the people of Britain deserve and I commend it to the House.

webTitle: Transport congestion

fields.headline: Transport congestion
fields.standfirst:
It barely featured as an issue at the last election but this year, transport has become a key political battleground. As John Prescott unveils his spending plans Julian Glover explains what lies behind gridlock Britain

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Transport barely featured as an issue at the last election but this year it has become a key political battleground. As John Prescott unveils his spending plans we explain what lies behind gridlock Britain
fields.body:
Why is transport in the news?
Two reasons. The immediate one is that Gordon Brown has boosted the government's transport budget, raising spending from its current £5bn to more than £9bn in 2003-4, an average annual increase of 20% a year in real terms. Spending on this scale should make a big difference to travel in Britain. Today the transport secretary, John Prescott will announce how he plans to use the money. The longer-term reason for transport's rising importance as an issue is that transport congestion - on the roads, in the skies and on the railways - is getting worse by the day. Some say traffic congestion costs the country £10bn a year. Politicians now worry that if they don't sort out the problem, they will lose votes and the economy will suffer.

Why is congestion getting worse?
Partly because Britain's getting richer. More people travel by train, for instance, when the economy is doing well, and more people can afford to drive cars. It's no coincidence that congestion is worst in London, the richest part of Britain. Partly, too, because society is changing: we have entered an age of what transport experts call 'hyper-mobility'. We expect to be able to travel where we want and when we want and complain when congestion means we can't.

Is Britain's transport system really as bad as we think? No. Compared with much of the world, Britain's transport system works rather well. London's taxi drivers moan non-stop about the city's traffic but they'd find things very much worse if they worked in Bangkok, Tokyo or Mexico City. Americans are impressed by our railways, even if we aren't, and Heathrow remains the world's biggest international destination. But set against the rest of the EU, transport in Britain is undeniably unimpressive.

Why? Money is at the root of the problem. Britain spends under 1% of its gross domestic product on transport, less than Germany, France, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland and as a result Britain's roads are five times more congested than Germany's, twice as congested as Italy's and 3.5 times more choked up than those of France. The chancellor's spending boost should help improve this aspect of the problem. But other causes will prove harder to tackle - geography, for instance. France has a far lower population density than Britain, and wealth is more evenly spread across the country. That makes it easier to establish a smooth-running transport network.

What will happen if we don't act? Analysts warn that road traffic could grow by 30% in the next 20 years and that congestion could rise even faster than that. Rail demand could go up by 30-50% in the next decade, as well. In 1979, there were 70 cars per mile of road. In 1997 there were 100 cars per mile of road, despite a transport policy that led to what the Conservative government called the 'biggest road-building programme since the Romans'.

And if we do? John Prescott's transport department is unveiling a 10-year plan which it promises will "transform the country's transport network" by tackling congestion bottlenecks on the roads, expanding railway capacity and building light rail networks. But it will steer clear of measures such as motorway tolls which might upset voters. Without draconian measures such as these some suspect little will change. Paris has fine public transport, for instance, but still sees terrible traffic jams. 81% of British motorists never use buses and getting them out of their cars will be a big job.

So the jams will go on? Yes. And beyond that, transport investment actually means they will get worse. Any improvement means a period of massive reconstruction which will see existing transport routes hugely disrupted. The west coast main rail line is now on the point of collapse because the builders bringing the line up to date get in the way of the business of running trains. London's Victoria line is closing for all of August simply to allow workers to replace some of its rails. Imagine how much chaos will be caused by a bigger reconstruction programme. And don't expect a smooth journey around Britain any time soon.

The Railway Development Society
The Road Haulage Association
