webTitle: Gillo Pontecorvo: The Battle of Algiers

fields.headline: Gillo Pontecorvo: The Battle of Algiers
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 77: Gillo Pontecorvo's The Battle of Algiers.
fields.body:
Few fictional films look more like documentary than Gillo Pontecorvo's The Battle of Algiers, and very few indeed which have this kind of socio-political structure and recount old, half-forgotten conflicts have achieved such lasting fame. Pontecorvo never managed to repeat the trick, though Queimada!, for which he hired Marlon Brando to play a British agent sent to the Caribbean to stir up rebellion against the Portuguese, was at least a partial success three years later.

The Battle of Algiers, however, remains the basis of Pontecorvo's fame - a model of how, without prejudice or compromise, a film-maker can illuminate history and tell us how we repeat the same mistakes. In fact, this study of the Algerian guerrilla struggle against the French colonialists in the 50s ought to be looked at not just as pure cinema but as a warning to those who seek by force to crush independence movements.

We know, of course, that Algeria was eventually liberated from the French, but Pontecorvo relegates that to an epilogue. He concentrates instead on the years between 1954 and 1957 when the freedom fighters regrouped and expanded into the casbah, only to face a systematic attempt by French paratroopers to wipe them out. His highly dramatic film is about the organisation of a guerrilla movement and the methods used to decimate it by the colonial power.

Its stance is as fair as any such film could be, despite the fact that Pontecorvo was a member of the Italian communist party at the time and thus was implicitly on the side of the independence movement. There is, though, no caricature and no glamorisation of either side - just a feeling of palpable horror evoked by urgent images and Ennio Morricone's dramatic but never melodramatic score. Pontecorvo sees the colonialists as victims of their own system, and the rebels as taking on some of the excesses used against them.

In one scene, a group of ordinary people, French and Algerian, are enjoying coffee and conversation near the casbah when a rebel bomb explodes among them. The shock of this sequence is even worse than the scenes of the French using torture.

The film is preceded by a message from the film-maker stating that "not one foot" of newsreel footage was used, but Marcello Gatti's grainy, black-and-white camera work in the actual locations of the struggle, and the pioneering use of a hand-held camera for the crowd scenes, makes it seem as if events are being recorded as they occur. The mixture of amateurs and professionals in the cast works admirably too.

In a way this is all cheating, and Pontecorvo once received as much criticism as praise. The left wanted more commitment to the rebel cause; the right complained that there was too much objectivity. Now, however, The Battle of Algiers is regarded as the precursor of films such as Francesco Rosi's Salvatore Giuliano and Costa-Gavras's Z - a film that allows its viewers to re-examine their own attitudes towards their times while making it clear that no one can prevent the march of history.

The film, which won the Golden Lion at the Venice Festival, was banned in France for some time and the torture scenes were cut from versions distributed in Britain and America. It can now be seen whole and is often shown as a model to those who wish to make either fiction or docudrama.

Credits

Writer-director Gillo Pontecorvo

Starring Jean Martin, Yacef Saadi

Original music Ennio Morricone

Italy/Algeria, 1965, 136 minutes

webTitle: Gamesmanship at Windward

fields.headline: Gamesmanship at Windward
fields.standfirst: This week and next we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText:
Day 5

U-12 v St Philip, U-13 v Windward
fields.body:
Day 5

U-12 v St Philip, U-13 v Windward

Windward is a different club: bigger, richer, with more sponsors. Apparently it is the second best ground on the island after Kensington Oval. The pitch was as dry as a bone, but still the groundsman apologised for only having used a massive motorized Test-match quality roller for three hours as opposed to five. He said that you could normally see your reflection in the pitch. Whether this was gamesmanship or truth or a bit of both we weren't sure. At any event I won the toss and put them in. There was a lot of banter and humour at the wicket, especially between myself and one or two more eccentric members of their side. While having a good time, we had a great game of cricket. We won, with a couple of overs in hand, against a very good, sharp, 11-year-old seamer (I wouldn't like to face him once he has grown) and some excellent batting. At one point their keeper, standing up, took the ball in front of the stumps and was no-balled for his pains. Our umpire asked him if he knew why. He said that he had taken the ball in front of the stumps but hoped the umpire wouldn't notice. Knowledge of the game and the finer points of its Laws are well developed out here! The U-12 fixture was cancelled first thing in the morning (apparently because the opposition could not travel on the weekend - but today is Friday!). Half an hour later a substitute fixture was arranged. Sadly, Dragon got thrashed, rumour has it by eight-year-olds.

webTitle: Too many white male judges, says Cherie Booth

fields.headline: Too many white male judges, says Cherie Booth
fields.trailText: The higher ranks of lawyers and judges must become more representative of the whole community if public confidence in the law and the justice system is to be maintained, Cherie Booth QC said yesterday.
fields.body:
The higher ranks of lawyers and judges must become more representative of the whole community if public confidence in the law and the justice system is to be maintained, Cherie Booth QC said yesterday.

The prime minister's wife told lawyers at the American Bar Association's millennium conference in London that figures for the numbers of women judges were "discouraging" and those for ethnic minorities even more disappointing.

Ms Booth, who sits as a part time judge, said there had never been a black high court judge, and few lawyers from ethnic minorities had reached the lower tiers of the judiciary.

The cost of training for a legal career increased the danger that it would be open only to the "privileged few".

Speaking on the challenges facing women and minorities, she quoted the former US president Lyndon Johnson: "It's not enough to open the gates of opportunity. All our citizens must have the means to walk through those gates."

It concerned her that "working class students, as I was, may not even be able to put their toe over the threshold of those gates of opportunity".

It was "a scandal that anyone with real talent should be barred from the profession simply because the cost of qualifying is so great". There were horror stories of students saddled with debts of £20,000 by the time they qualified.

Ms Booth, who specialises in equality and employment law, denied that she was calling for quotas or positive discrimination to boost the prospects of women and ethnic minorities.

"What I ask for is not positive discrimination but prevention of direct and the even more insidious indirect discrimination. What we have to do is find criteria for the jobs we are doing that are not based on assumptions of what a real lawyer looks like that boils down to a white middle class male."

 More than 11% of criminal cases brought to the courts were dropped by the prosecution before they had reached their natural conclusion, wasting millions of pounds, according to the crown prosecution service annual report for 1999-2000. In 1997-98 the proportion was 7%.

Reasons for failures include missing witnesses, shortcomings in the prosecution case and defendants with serious medical problems.

The number of discontinuances in magistrates' cases rose from 11.9% last year to 12.2% this year.

webTitle: Rumours raging over American Harry Potter

fields.headline: Rumours raging over American Harry Potter
fields.trailText: The Harry Potter rumour mill has been going into overdrive this week, with the news that the makers of the picture appear set to brave the wrath of a legion of fans by casting an American actor as the child wizard
fields.body:
The Harry Potter rumour mill has been going into overdrive this week, with the news that the makers of the picture appear set to brave the wrath of a legion of fans by casting an American actor as the child wizard.

It is rumoured that New Jersey nipper Liam Aiken is one of the front-runners to take the role. The 10-year-old actor is said to be the top choice of director Chris Columbus, who directed the child in last year's saccharine weepy Stepmom.

The Americanisation of Potter has long been the biggest bone of contention surrounding the film. Steven Spielberg allegedly pulled out of directing the picture after British author JK Rowling objected to his plans to cast The Sixth Sense star Haley Joel Osment in the lead, while Warner Bros have been insistent in their assurances that their adaptation will remain true to the book's British roots (see last week's story). The suggestion that Liam Aiken was even on the shortlist is rumoured to have been behind British casting director Susie Figgis' decision to quit the project (see our earlier story).

Just to add to the confusion, in a BBC Radio 1 interview today Rowling confirms that she rang Columbus this week to double check Liam Aiken had not been cast, and was reassured that he had not. She said that no casting would be confirmed until the boy wizard had been found, and that final auditions should be soon.

In the meantime, Entertainment Weekly has this week been digesting the other casting rumours. The magazine reports that Tim Roth is in line to play Professor Snape, and Robbie Coltrane will appear as Hagrid. As mentioned in our news report two weeks ago, Maggie Smith is tipped to take on the role of Professor McGonagall.

webTitle: Overfishing and global warming land cod on endangered list

fields.headline: Overfishing and global warming land cod on endangered list
fields.trailText: Cod is to be added to a list of endangered species by WWF amid fears that Britain's traditional dish of fish and chips is to disappear along with thousands of fishing industry jobs.
fields.body:
Cod is to be added to a list of endangered species by WWF amid fears that Britain's traditional dish of fish and chips is to disappear along with thousands of fishing industry jobs.

WWF, the global environmental network formerly known as the World Wide Fund for Nature, will claim the species is already threatened with virtual extinction by overfishing as it launches its Oceans Recovery Campaign (Orca) today, which aims to raise awareness of the plight of the UK's marine environment.

Cod stocks in the North Sea are down to one-tenth of the level 30 years ago. The catch used to be 250,000 tonnes a year but the maximum permitted cod catch this year under EU rules is 34,301 tonnes, but even this seems far too high. Catches to July 13 were 13,305 tonnes - so low because fishermen, even with radar and sophisticated satellite tracking equipment, just cannot find the fish.

Scientists fear that North Sea cod may go the way of those in the Grand Banks of Canada, where overfished stocks disappeared in 1992 and have not revived.

Elliott Morely, the fisheries minister, said the North Sea cod's plight had been caused over 20 years by the failure of EU and successive fisheries ministers to take scientific advice seriously, and quotas for catches being fixed too high.

"The results have been disastrous. That is why we are trying to do something about it now with all sorts of conservation measures, drastic cuts in quotas, nets that let the juvenile fish escape. Everyone realises what a mess cod are in."

The plight of the once numerous fish has not been helped by changes in water temperature in the North Sea which has increased up to 3C. Cod prefers cold water and the rise in temperature, which some ascribe to global warming, has damaged cod's ability to spawn. But no one doubts that overfishing is the primary cause of the fish's decline.

Barry Dees, the chief executive of the national federation of fishermen's organisations, said: "The common fisheries policy has clearly not worked. We need a fundamental change, we need to manage zones of the sea. This includes no-take zones, seasonally closed areas, special nets to allow juvenile fish to escape. Each area needs its own special agreements and measures to protect the stocks.

"The EU dictating solutions to fishermen from afar is resented and has not worked. I still think it can be done, stock can recover, there is still all to play for."

WWF described cod, which is worth more than £40m a year to the Scottish fishing fleet, as a "potent symbol of decline" in the state of the oceans. According to the organisation, haddock, the mainstay of the fish supper in Scotland, is less depleted but its long-term future is just as insecure.

A spokesman for WWF said the decision to place cod on the endangered species list was a warning bell to draw attention to the fact that urgent action was required.

Alastair Davison, a marine specialist at WWF Scotland, said: "The ocean recovery campaign is about much more than saving wildlife. Unless we take action to regenerate fish stocks, jobs in the fishing industry and the future of coastal communities will continue to suffer decline and be at risk.

"More than 70% of the UK fishing fleet is based in Scotland. The risk of commercial extinction of fish stocks jeopardises the jobs of the 15,000 full-time and 3,500 part-time fishermen in the UK, not to mention the whole economy of coastal communities."

He added: "We're not asking people to stop fishing or eating fish. Fishermen and WWF share the same goal - abundant fish stocks in healthy seas. Marine life needs safe havens to survive and regenerate, and creating room for living seas is simply an investment in the future."

Orca wants government action to regenerate the seas, including the piloting of fishing-free zones and a stronger network of protected areas.

Cod lore

 Cod can live 20 years and grow to 5ft but most are caught between two and four years before they reach sexual maturity

 Cold water is needed for breeding so they spawn from January to April

 Females produce up to 4m eggs but 98% get eaten before hatching, mostly by herring

 Cod mostly eat other fish, sand eels, pout, herring, dab and shrimps

 According to scientists, cod are "outside safe biological limits", which means there may not be enough breeding stock left to stop the species disappearing

webTitle: PM's Japan appeal to aid missing girl's family

fields.headline: PM's Japan appeal to aid missing girl's family
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair made a special diversion during his visit to Tokyo for the G8 summit to meet the father of missing air stewardess Lucie Blackman
Special report: Debt relief
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today made a personal appeal to the people of Japan to come forward with any leads in the search for Lucie Blackman - the former British Airways stewardess who disappeared while working as a bar hostess in Tokyo.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today made a personal appeal to the people of Japan to come forward with any leads in the search for Lucie Blackman - the former British Airways stewardess who disappeared while working as a bar hostess in Tokyo.

Mr Blair met Ms Blackman's father, Tim, and her sister, Sophie, as soon as he arrived in the Japanese capital to attend the G8 summit of world leaders. The prime minister invited Mr Blackman to his hotel, near the headquarters of the summit's first phase, to discuss the progress Japanese police had made so far in solving the mystery of Lucie's disappearance.

Afterwards, Mr Blair said: "It's obviously an appalling, heartbreaking story, and every parent's nightmare is to have their child working abroad and then disappear. What I have said is that we will do everything we can.

"We are working closely with the Japanese authorities here and obviously we appeal to people in Japan who may know about the case to come forward and give us some leads we can follow up."

The meeting was Mr Blair's first stop on arrival in Tokyo before plunging into a round of discussions with world leaders for the G8 summit, which ends on Sunday.

In the run-up to the summit, Greenpeace, the environmental group, urged G8 leaders to stop government subsidies it said were helping to destroy the earth's remaining ancient forests.

The environmental organisation presented a new report from the Washington-based World Resources Institute (WRI), which said destruction of remaining pristine forests was subsidised by G8 governments to the tune of more than $3bn.

The heads of the world's leading industrialised countries are also expected to come under pressure from campaigners to move more quickly on previous pledges to cancel the debts of poor countries.

webTitle: July 20: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: July 20: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Myers recruits private-eye, Depardieu discharged, and Anne Heche, William H Macy and Bruce Willis on the casting couch
fields.body:
 The increasingly surreal lawsuit between Mike Myers (pictured) and Universal (see our earlier story) took another twist last night with reports that the Austin Powers star has recruited private-eye Anthony Pellicano to fight in his corner. Pellicano, who has worked for the likes of Kevin Costner and Michael Jackson, is notorious for his hard-ball tactics which commonly involve digging up dirt to discredit his opponents. Myers is being sued by Universal for bailing out of the monkey-comedy Dieter but is counter-suing the studio over alleged harrassment. This one looks set to run and run.

 Gerard Depardieu was discharged from hospital last night following his heart bypass operation. "He is in very good form but will now rest for three weeks at home," said his agent Claude Davy. Depardieu, who is known for his love of food and wine, has been ordered to change his lifestyle in the wake of the health scare, though film-makers will hope that he delays his diet until after his next picture. Next month he is due to reprise his role as the bloated, boar-eating Obelix in the kids' film Asterix and Cleopatra.

 Anne Heche is in final talks to join Denzel Washington and Robert Duvall in New Line's hostage thriller John Q. Washington will star as an impoverished dad who lays siege to an operating theatre in order to gain a heart transplant for his sickly son. Duvall plays the hostage negotiator, while Heche is in line to play the by-the-book hospital administrator.

 The great William H Macy (of Fargo and Boogie Nights fame) is to co-star in Jurassic Park 3, with the third instalment in Spielberg's dinosaur franchise to be directed by Joe Johnston. The picture, backed in a joint venture by Universal and DreamWorks, shoots in Hawaii later this year and the script remains tightly under wraps. Sources, however, claim that Macy will play the role of an unscrupulous millionaire businessman, so expect him to end up in a T-rex's stomach somewhere around the midway mark.

 Time is ticking out on the making of the long-awaited Die Hard prequel, as regular star Bruce Willis creeps towards his fiftieth birthday. "I'm waiting for a great script for a film before the first Die Hard," Willis told reporters this week. "They better hurry though, 'cos I'm not getting any younger."

webTitle: A bum deal

fields.headline: A bum deal
fields.standfirst: The whole point of the thong is its invisibility. So why are we seeing them everywhere, asks  Louisa Young
fields.trailText: The whole point of the thong is its invisibility. So why are we seeing them everywhere, asks  Louisa Young.
fields.body:
Whizzing down the street on my bicycle, standing up on the pedals, my trousers are a little baggy, hanging on my hipbones. I am not a natural midriff-barer, a pierced-navel kind of girl, but cruising like this I feel a little thin, a little fit, and cool and summery. It's a good feeling. Curious that trousers falling down should make you feel cool - but they do.

And I am not alone in feeling this. All around me I see girls doing the thing boys did a year or two back to display the waistband of their Calvin knickers: letting those hipsters go. And what they reveal is the bit of elastic and telltale triangle that denote the thong.

The thong used to be a G-string; it was a sexual piece of kit, on a par with a peephole bra. When Monica Lewinsky let Bill Clinton catch a glimpse of hers it was: Ohh! But the thong is now ubiquitous. Sales are up 50% on last year, says the man from M&S. One tabloid ran a whole page of celebrity visible-thong pictures, glimpsed at that moment when the concentration, as well as the trousers, slips. All of us can see hoi polloi thongs any Saturday night at the Slug and Lettuce.

There's even a massive picture of one on a poster in Knightsbridge, west London, showing a tiny man with a lawnmower seeing to the "bikini line". We are shown this female trouserless from below the waist to the upper thigh; the poster is the size of a shopfront. I can't tell you what it's advertising because I was too bemused that someone felt the need to put a close-up of a 20ft mons veneris in a public place.

But it's not surprising that this is happening. More, more, more - or, rather, less, less, less - is the rule for advertisers, salesmen and seekers of extremity in the pursuit of profit, because, of course, less (clothes on women) is more (dosh in the pockets of capitalism). In the wake of this, we are all sexualised to within an inch of our lives. Underwear as outerwear used to concentrate on bras and basques, bosoms and cleavages, but that's so 30 seconds ago - been there done that, sold loads of them, let's move on.

Arse is the new tit, builder's bum is the new cleavage, thong is the new Wonderbra, and that little triangle below the small of the back is the new glimpse of lace when a button pops open.

The only thing is, now we're doing it on purpose - which gives a kind of knowingness to the display which, according to the traditions of our culture, looks either tarty or desperate for attention. The goddess Fashion is for so many young women She Who Must Be Obeyed, but combining this obligation to display with the low esteem in which most girls hold their body is a pretty potent recipe for female personal confusion.

If you don't wear thongs, and just quietly carry on wearing what you've always worn, you somehow transmogrify into the opposite: a big knickers kind of woman, with all that that implies: old, boring, fat, not getting any.

It was only 100 years ago that gentlemen went into palpitations at the sight of an ankle (we all know where legs lead, after all) and even piano legs had to wear long knickers. Only 50 years ago Cole Porter observed that "In olden days a glimpse of stocking was looked on as something shocking, now - heaven knows! Anything goes!"

And today? Soon there will be nowhere else to go. Actual nudity will never work for fashion because there's no money to be made from it. Perhaps we will follow the thong down between the buttocks and, yeah, maybe next week we'll be wearing periscopes up our arses, or video screen T-shirts showing fibre-optic pictures of our small intestines.

Or maybe we'll go to Brazil where the thong was invented, and has always been best displayed. This season, the perfectly beautiful young Brazilians who look so fabulous in it consider the thong to be rather naff and old-fashioned. Something their mothers might wear.

The discerning girl from Ipanema is wearing bigger knickers. Why do I find that so amusing?

Tree of Pearls by Louisa Young is published by Flamingo on August 8.

webTitle: Shipman inquiry should be held in public, court rules

fields.headline: Shipman inquiry should be held in public, court rules
fields.trailText: Relatives of the victims of serial killer GP Harold Shipman have won their High Court battle for an open inquiry. The ruling was announced a short time ago at the Royal Courts of Justice in central London.
fields.body:
Relatives of the victims of serial killer GP Harold Shipman have won their High Court battle for an open inquiry. The ruling was announced a short time ago at the Royal Courts of Justice in central London.

Over 100 relatives, backed by the media, had sought the order which would force Health Secretary Alan Milburn to hold a public investigation "to restore faith and confidence in GPs and the NHS".

Today Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Jackson, ruled the decision to sit in private "contravenes Article 10 of the European Convention of Human Rights in that it constitutes unjustified governmental interference with the reception of information that others wish or may be willing to impart".

Earlier this year Shipman, 54, of Mottram in Longendale, Greater Manchester, was convicted at Preston Crown Court of murdering 15 patients at Hyde, Cheshire, but he is suspected of killing nearly 200.

At a recent hearing, family lawyers urged Lord Justice Kennedy and Mr Justice Jackson to intervene over the investigation into the deaths. They argued that Mr Milburn had been wrong to direct evidence to be given in private, and stressed that an open hearing was vital.

But earlier David Elvin QC, appearing for the Health Secretary, had said the families had no "legitimate expectation" that the inquiry would be in public. The decision to hold it in private was plainly not irrational, he argued, and Mr Milburn had been entitled to decide that a private hearing was the best way to obtain evidence and implement any recommended reforms as quickly as possible.

Richard Gordon QC, appearing for inquiry chairman Lord Laming, said tensions were resulting from the fact that the inquiry was not going to be as broad as the families of those who died would like.

The Health Secretary was granted leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal, although Lord Justice Kennedy said: "We don't necessarily encourage him to take advantage of that leave."

webTitle: Injured Neeson doubtful for Scorsese film

fields.headline: Injured Neeson doubtful for Scorsese film
fields.trailText: Liam Neeson has been making slow progress following last week's collision with a jaywalking deer and may not have recovered in time to star in The Gangs of New York
fields.body:
Lassie aside, it's rare for a humble animal to make an impact on cinema history, but if Liam Neeson is forced to pull out of the new Scorsese picture, he would be forgiven for blaming his ill-fortune on a jaywalking deer.

Since last week's collision with the creature, the Irish actor has been making slow, painful progress. Neeson was scheduled to star as Leonardo DiCaprio's father in Scorsese's Gangs of New York, but the film's backers are rumoured to be increasingly uncertain as to whether Neeson will have recovered in time - the film has a start date of August 30.

Neeson was riding his 1989 Harley Davidson when he hit the deer on a country road in upstate New York and was discovered crawling along the hard-shoulder by a passerby. He was moved to Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, where he underwent a four-hour operation to repair a fractured right pelvis. Last night Neeson's spokesman Alan Nierob sounded a cautiously optimistic note, saying that the actor was "fine from the waist up". But an unnamed friend has admitted that "his injuries were a lot more serious than people thought. There was significant internal bleeding and other complications. He was very close to going into shock."

Representatives for Scorsese are reported to be remaining hopeful that Neeson will still be able to join The Gangs of New York, but, significantly, stressed that he had not yet signed on the dotted line - leaving them an easy escape route to cast another actor in his place. But however woeful Neeson is feeling at present, at least he got off more lightly than the luckless deer, which was found dead at the scene.

webTitle: Judges begin Pinochet review

fields.headline: Judges begin Pinochet review
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Pinochet on trial
Audio: Jonathan Franklin in Santiago
fields.trailText: The Chilean supreme court yesterday heard the first of three days of arguments before it will decide whether to accept a 13-9 vote by a lower court to strip Augusto Pinochet of his senatorial immunity and allow 19 kidnapping charges to move forward.
fields.body:
The Chilean supreme court yesterday heard the first of three days of arguments before it will decide whether to accept a 13-9 vote by a lower court to strip Augusto Pinochet of his senatorial immunity and allow 19 kidnapping charges to move forward.

The 84-year-old former dictator's defence team had fought bitterly to avoid the hearing, arguing for the right to present medical evidence that it claims would demonstrate that Gen Pinochet was physically and mentally unfit to stand trial.

The court is expected to give its ruling in about a month. However, should it allow the medical arguments to be heard before the decision, Pinochet could be declared unfit for trial and allowed to live out his remaining years a free man.

The prosecuting lawyer, Hiram Villegra, ridiculed the medical argument. "He [Pinochet] says he can't meet with his lawyers, but he gathers with his children, receives generals. His own son said that Pinochet is directing his own defence."

Outside the Santiago courtroom, a meagre group of nine Pinochet supporters waved Chilean flags and held signs that read: "The General He Saved Us From Terrorism". Dozens of riot police staked out the downtown area to prevent clashes between pro- and anti-Pinochet groups, but the cold winter morning and interminable legal processes contributed to a practically non-existent public turnout.

"This is the continuation of a political vendetta versus the military government," insisted Marcelo Cabrera, 25. "From the time that Pinochet was kidnapped in London, the left has continued the politics of vengeance." Mr Cabrera, the president of a radical pro-Pinochet group, even defended the politics of "disappearing" political prisoners. "If you understand the climate of violence in Chile during those years, you can justify it."

The disappeared are at the centre of the court case against Pinochet. In particular, the judges are investigating his role in authorising a high-level mission by the then army general Sergio Arellano Stark to visit prisons throughout Chile in October 1973, just a month after the military coup led by the armed forces. Various army generals have testified to the investigating judge, Juan Guzman, that on arrival at their command posts, Stark displayed a handwritten note (since disappeared) in which Pinochet delegated him as his representative.

In nearly every location where Stark touched down in his helicopter, massacres were immediately ordered.

About 75 political prisoners were executed and in 19 cases the bodies were then "disappeared". It is those missing corpses that opened a judicial loophole through which Judge Guzman has circumvented Pinochet's self-declared amn-esty law.

The prosecution is also appealing against aspects of the appeals court ruling that the ex-dictator ought to lose his immunity. Plaintiff lawyers are arguing that should he lose his immunity the decision ought to be applicable to all 147 criminal cases and not only the "Caravan of Death" case.

In recent press statements, Pinochet's defence team has argued that its client is an innocent victim of political persecution.

Mr Villegra said bringing Pinochet into the court system was a victory in the "civilising" of the Chilean army. He argued that history had already been made, regardless of the final outcome. "If, for whatever motive, Pinochet is not sentenced at least this effort has permitted the justice system to recover its role and prestige."

The Pinochet defence strategy will focus on the arguments that Chilean society was in a state of war when the army massacres were carried out.

An estimated 5,000 Chileans were murdered and tens of thousands tortured during the Pinochet regime. The state-sponsored violence was most brutal during the first three years after the 1973 coup that led to the overthrow and immediate death of the socialist president, Salvador Allende.

webTitle: Okinawa

fields.headline: Okinawa
fields.standfirst: All about the Japanese archipelago where the world's most powerful leaders are meeting for the G8 summit
fields.trailText: All about the Japanese archipelago where the world's most powerful leaders are meeting for the G8 summit
fields.body:
1. Strategically situated halfway between the main Japanese archipelago and Taiwan, Okinawa was the scene of the last great battle of the second world war.

2. More than 200,000 soldiers and civilians - nearly 95% of them Japanese - died in three months of bitter fighting.

3. The scale of the slaughter on Okinawa was one of the main factors in the US decision to drop atom bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, rather than risk an invasion of the Japanese heartlands.

4. After the war, Okinawa remained under US military rule until 1972, when it reverted to Japanese rule. Some 20% of the land was confiscated to build sprawling airfields and bases.

5. US-Okinawan tension, never far from the surface, erupted into angry protests in 1995 when three US Marines were convicted of raping a 12-year-old schoolgirl.

6. The American ambassador in Tokyo, Walter Mondale, was forced formally to apologise, but that did little to assuage Japanese feelings. Many Americans too were deeply affronted.

7. Today Okinawa remains the massively fortified home to some 50,000 US service personnel, to the chagrin of locals.

8. Okinawa remains a powerful symbol of world conflict. But the G8 leaders will have little scope on their agenda for discussing war and peace.

9. Instead, they will devote much of their time to pondering the enormous gap in IT resources between rich and poor nations.

10. There will also be a discussion of Third World debt - but nobody expects any dramatic progress towards debt reduction.

webTitle: Web watch

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Coffee break | Olympic clash
fields.body:
Coffee break
Internet audio portal, http://Angrycoffee.com has just added an MP3 search engine that can access the Napster network from the web. The Percolator is slightly faster than Napster because the web-based interface allows only downloads. There is no facility to allow other users to upload from your hard drive, which is bound to annoy the purists. To lessen charges that the site is merely piggybacking, the Percolator places tracks by unsigned, independent artists alongside each search result, and no fee is asked for any of the tracks.

Olympic clash
The millennium Olympics do not start until September 15, but already there are clashes behind the scenes far fiercer than those which will be seen on track and field. Aboriginal groups are calling for a boycott of the games in support of their demands for for greater autonomy. Environmentalists are targeting individual sponsors (see www.cokespotlight.org). Even local residents are taking the opportunity to campaign for lower rents see www.rw.apana.org.au.

The Anti-Olympic Alliance is trying to unite the different protest groups - there are at least 40 - and two independent media sites have been set up at http://sydney.indymedia.org and www.samcentre.org.

To the woods
You really need a superfast connection to fully appreciate the kooky site at www.once-upon-a-forest.com. Is it net art or just an elaborate hoax? Who cares, when it is done as beautifully as this? Equally bizarre is www.soulbath.com, the online plaything of Hi-Res, one of London's trendiest web development agencies. It pretends to be an anti-banner site, but does this by producing some very pretty banners indeed.

Green power
Servista is the latest service provider to offer unmetered internet access for users of its telephone service. It will also supply gas and electricity and put them all on one e-bill. The company even claims to guarantee that it can supply households with electricity from renewable sources, though a monthly surcharge - roughly £1.40 per month for the average household - will be added to the bill. See www.servista.com.

Big brother
Channel 4's new series, Big Brother, might have been inspired by the likes of the now classic Jennycam.com, but its supporting website at www.channel4.com/bigbrother is tame by comparison. And quite what George Orwell would make of the Big Brother pizza from Domino's, does not bear thinking about. Maybe he would have advocated the fledgling net privacy site at www.bigbrother.org, or wryly smiled at the simple joke at www.bigbrother.com.

New and noted
www.thehorsesmouth.co.uk is a new portal for horse racing fans; www.bulletinmail.com offers email for cell phones. Alertnet is Reuters' new news service. A complete guide to making paper aeroplanes is online at www.paperairplanes.co.uk.

Catalan culture centre

Official site
www.barcelonaturisme.com
Joan Miro museum
www.bcn.fjmiro.es
Bus and Metro timetables
www.tmb.net/welcome.html

webTitle: Police investigating Sarah Payne murder find girl's shoe

fields.headline: Police investigating Sarah Payne murder find girl's shoe
fields.trailText: Police investigating the murder of Sarah Payne confirmed today that they had found a girl's black shoe near the spot where her body was discovered on Monday. The shoe was found in a hedge in Coolham, West Sussex, about a mile from Pulborough where the eight-year-old's  body was retrieved.
fields.body:
Police investigating the murder of Sarah Payne confirmed today that they had found a girl's black shoe near the spot where her body was discovered on Monday. The shoe was found in a hedge in Coolham, West Sussex, about a mile from Pulborough where the eight-year-old's body was retrieved.

Meanwhile, campers say they heard a little girl's screams on the night murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne vanished in West Sussex.

But they have only just come forward to report the cries after realising their campsite was near where the eight-year-old's body was discovered.

Police say they have taken statements from the two young couples who told them they were concerned about the screams but did not attach sufficient importance to them.

They were camped at Fittleworth beauty spot on the weekend Sarah disappeared, three miles from where her body was found on Monday near Pulborough.

The development came as Sarah's distraught parents begged the nation for help in finding her killer.

In their first public appeal since the eight-year-old's body was found, Michael and Sara Payne were choked with emotion as they made the heart-rending plea.

Later they broke down and sobbed after seeing the hundreds of flowers, toys and cards which had been left by the roadside near the spot where her body was dumped.

An appeal fund has been set up by police for the parents as a focus for the hundreds of people who have sent money for the family in the wake of Sarah's death.

At an emotionally-charged news conference the couple said public support had kept them strong throughout their 18-day ordeal. Police have received more than 28,000 calls in connection with the inquiry.

Mr and Mrs Payne, both 31, from Hersham, Surrey, told reporters at Littlehampton police station in West Sussex: "We've got a job now and that's to catch this person, or persons...whoever it is has got to be stopped."

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip, given fifty overs to reach a respectable target
fields.trailText: Bryan Robson wants to lift the hearts of Middlesbrough supporters, according to the Sun, and is ready to spend £15m on Liverpool's Robbie Fowler. The paper claims that Robson is aware of the Merseysiders' interest in Boro wing-back Christian Ziege and hopes to arrange a player-plus-cash swap deal to bring Fowler to the north-east. Why the England international would want to swap his home town, and European football, for the Riverside is not quite explained.
fields.body:
Bryan Robson wants to lift the hearts of Middlesbrough supporters, according to the Sun, and is ready to spend £15m on Liverpool's Robbie Fowler. The paper claims that Robson is aware of the Merseysiders' interest in Boro wing-back Christian Ziege and hopes to arrange a player-plus-cash swap deal to bring Fowler to the north-east. Why the England international would want to swap his home town, and European football, for the Riverside is not quite explained.

If Aston Villa fail to sign Neil Lennon from Leicester, he will try and buy Frank Lampard instead. The Sun suggests that Lennon is likely to join former manager Martin O'Neill at Celtic for £6m, and that John Gregory will attempt to persuade Harry Redknapp to sell one of his most valued young players.

Aston Villa are also in the market for Juninho, and an attempt to sign the Brazilian playmaker could prove more successful. Juninho's father, who doubles as his agent, told the Mirror today: "Aston Villa are prepared to meet Atletico's demands. I am hopeful that all parties will be able to reach an agreement within the next few days."

Leeds have denied an interest in Roda JC's Belgian international defender Joos Valgaeren. Reports had suggested that the Yorkshire club had made a £3.5m bid for him, but Peter Ridsdale said today: "We have no interest whatsoever in Joos Valgaeren."

Charlton are chasing South Africa skipper Shaun Bartlett. The 27-year-old forward, who plays for FC Zurich, would cost the Premiership newcomers £2.5m says the Sun.

Arsenal have taken Bulgarian international defender Radostan Kishishev on trial according to the Daily Mail.

webTitle: Dear Anna

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Repairing the damage

For those of us obliged to rely on Britain's now-you-see-it-now-you-don't transport system, the only consolation is the thought of the huge insurance premiums paid by the car drivers who speed by us. That comfort is to become even more consoling as premiums are set to soar by up to 2% a month over the next year.

One reason is the numerous mergers within the insurance industry which has swallowed competition and killed off smaller independents. Prices, insiders lament, have been kept artificially low in the cut-throat market of the 90s; now the surviving big boys can flex their muscles, hike prices and "streamline" the range of policy types once offered by their rivals.

So what is it that drivers get for their £600-odd a year? V Mitchell of Cardiff surrendered her car to Endsleigh insurance after an accident and emphasised that she wanted a repair for sentimental reasons even if she had to contribute towards it. However, after two weeks of waiting she was told the vehicle was a write-off and had been taken to a salvage yard.

She was offered £500 if she accepted it back unrepaired and £800 if it was scrapped. "This," she says, "despite the fact that it was insured for £1,600." When the car was eventually returned she found that it had been stripped of its battery and spare wheel. Five weeks on she was still waiting for a cheque and replacement parts.

"We can see exactly why she's so frustrated," says an eager young spokesman. "The car was tampered with and filleted and pilfered and we are cap in hand." The car was taken to the scrapyard simply to be stored safely, he points out, although usually owners are warned of this beforehand. As for the measly recompense, it's one of the joys of being an insurer that they are allowed to offer the policy value or the market value, whichever is the lower. In this case the car was worth less than the policy, but, in its contrition, Endsleigh has now agreed to fund the full cost of the "uneconomical" repair.

The cost of courtesy

Elisabeth Standen is a disabled passenger who, last March, travelled with Wales & West trains from Bristol to Yatton. She checked the facilities on the helpline beforehand, but found that on the return leg there was no ramp. Instead, her friend and a fellow passenger lifted her into the carriage, after which the guard appeared and tried to prevent the friend from leaving the train.

"She told her that she could not take responsibility for me and behaved as though my friend were trying to abandon a baby," she says.

The same guard told Standen that staff at Bristol would help her out of the carriage, but no one appeared. This time the taxi driver, whom Standen had booked to meet her, lifted her down, but the guard tried to prevent her from taking Standen to her cab. "Her behaviour was completely out of order as the driver was clearly wearing an identity badge and we were both obviously on first name terms," she says. Standen wrote a letter complaining of her humiliation in March but never received a reply.

Courtesy levels in Wales & West HQ are no improvement on those on Standen's train. A weary-sounding spokeswoman agrees to investigate and that's the last we hear from her.

Weeks later, when Consumer manages to track her down, the exchange goes something like this: "Mrs Standen has apologised to us for contacting you because we have resolved it." "Was it resolved after we intervened?" "Yes." "So why has she had to apologise." "Don't know."

Our amiable contact refuses to comment further, but Standen has just reported that an apology and a goodwill cheque for £15 has since arrived in the post.

Charging for change

NatWest has this week invested in pages of smug adverts, boasting of how they have cut their charges and become champions of altruism. Mary Gill was therefore surprised to be asked if she was a NatWest account holder when she asked the bank to change a £20 note, freshly dispensed from its cashpoint, into fivers. "I was told that if I were not, I'd be charged £3 for a transaction that took all of 10 seconds," she says.

"It's a discretionary charge," says a NatWest spokeswoman. "If a customer came in for change for a bus and it was raining we'd be sympathetic, but if you walk in every day and want change for your antiques business we'd charge a fee."

A spokesman from the National Association of Bank and Insurance customers takes a more robust view: "It's another way for banks to try to make you become a customer by not doing business with anyone who isn't one."

Men come first - it's in the small print

Recently we published a disgruntled enquiry from a reader who found herself unable to vote in Standard Life's demutualisation ballot. Her husband's name came first on their joint account which meant that he was the nominal account holder with the sole right to vote. The man's name, as she pointed out, is traditionally put first and no one at the building society had ever asked the couple for their preference.

Geraldine Simmons of Merseyside will also find herself out of pocket because of the system. Three years ago she and her ex-husband remortgaged their home through Bradford & Bingley and his name appeared first on the policy. At the end of last year she transferred the account into her name only. Shortly afterwards, borrowers who had taken out their loan before April 1999 were told they would receive shares if the company floated on the stock market, but Simmons found herself ineligible because during the qualifying period her ex-husband was the official account holder.

"As far as I am aware we were not asked which name we wished to appear first," she says. "Now neither of us will receive anything."

Bradford & Bingley points to its terms and conditions which do explain (at the end of the eighth section) that the first name in a joint account is the nominal account holder with sole right to vote. Women beware - always read the small print.

An ink cartridge is not just an ink cartridge

David Godfrey of Twickenham wants to know how retailers can justify charging £26 for a 28ml ink cartridge used in his computer printer. "This works out at just under £1,080 per litre of ink," he rages. "What's so special about it?"

More than the layman could ever fathom, according to a spokesman for the Dixons group which sells large numbers of such cartridges. "Over the past five years printers have dropped in price and part of their hi-tech facilities have been transferred to the cartridges," he says.

So those bland plastic refills might contain their own in-built printer head, fade-proof ink, and a micro-chip or two. Really posh ones can deliver ink droplets of four million millionth of a litre to print fine quality photographs.

They can't yet brew your early morning cuppa, alas, but doubtless that will come.

fields.bodyText: Repairing the damage For those of us obliged to rely on Britain's now-you-see-it-now-you-don't transport system, the only consolation is the thought of the huge insurance premiums paid by the car drivers who speed by us. That comfort is to become even more consoling as premiums are set to soar by up to 2% a month over the next year. One reason is the numerous mergers within the insurance industry which has swallowed competition and killed off smaller independents. Prices, insiders lament, have been kept artificially low in the cut-throat market of the 90s; now the surviving big boys can flex their muscles, hike prices and "streamline" the range of policy types once offered by their rivals. So what is it that drivers get for their £600-odd a year? V Mitchell of Cardiff surrendered her car to Endsleigh insurance after an accident and emphasised that she wanted a repair for sentimental reasons even if she had to contribute towards it. However, after two weeks of waiting she was told the vehicle was a write-off and had been taken to a salvage yard. She was offered £500 if she accepted it back unrepaired and £800 if it was scrapped. "This," she says, "despite the fact that it was insured for £1,600." When the car was eventually returned she found that it had been stripped of its battery and spare wheel. Five weeks on she was still waiting for a cheque and replacement parts. "We can see exactly why she's so frustrated," says an eager young spokesman. "The car was tampered with and filleted and pilfered and we are cap in hand." The car was taken to the scrapyard simply to be stored safely, he points out, although usually owners are warned of this beforehand. As for the measly recompense, it's one of the joys of being an insurer that they are allowed to offer the policy value or the market value, whichever is the lower. In this case the car was worth less than the policy, but, in its contrition, Endsleigh has now agreed to fund the full cost of the "uneconomical" repair. The cost of courtesy Elisabeth Standen is a disabled passenger who, last March, travelled with Wales & West trains from Bristol to Yatton. She checked the facilities on the helpline beforehand, but found that on the return leg there was no ramp. Instead, her friend and a fellow passenger lifted her into the carriage, after which the guard appeared and tried to prevent the friend from leaving the train. "She told her that she could not take responsibility for me and behaved as though my friend were trying to abandon a baby," she says. The same guard told Standen that staff at Bristol would help her out of the carriage, but no one appeared. This time the taxi driver, whom Standen had booked to meet her, lifted her down, but the guard tried to prevent her from taking Standen to her cab. "Her behaviour was completely out of order as the driver was clearly wearing an identity badge and we were both obviously on first name terms," she says. Standen wrote a letter complaining of her humiliation in March but never received a reply. Courtesy levels in Wales & West HQ are no improvement on those on Standen's train. A weary-sounding spokeswoman agrees to investigate and that's the last we hear from her. Weeks later, when Consumer manages to track her down, the exchange goes something like this: "Mrs Standen has apologised to us for contacting you because we have resolved it." "Was it resolved after we intervened?" "Yes." "So why has she had to apologise." "Don't know." Our amiable contact refuses to comment further, but Standen has just reported that an apology and a goodwill cheque for £15 has since arrived in the post. Charging for change NatWest has this week invested in pages of smug adverts, boasting of how they have cut their charges and become champions of altruism. Mary Gill was therefore surprised to be asked if she was a NatWest account holder when she asked the bank to change a £20 note, freshly dispensed from its cashpoint, into fivers. "I was told that if I were not, I'd be charged £3 for a transaction that took all of 10 seconds," she says. "It's a discretionary charge," says a NatWest spokeswoman. "If a customer came in for change for a bus and it was raining we'd be sympathetic, but if you walk in every day and want change for your antiques business we'd charge a fee." A spokesman from the National Association of Bank and Insurance customers takes a more robust view: "It's another way for banks to try to make you become a customer by not doing business with anyone who isn't one." Men come first - it's in the small print Recently we published a disgruntled enquiry from a reader who found herself unable to vote in Standard Life's demutualisation ballot. Her husband's name came first on their joint account which meant that he was the nominal account holder with the sole right to vote. The man's name, as she pointed out, is traditionally put first and no one at the building society had ever asked the couple for their preference. Geraldine Simmons of Merseyside will also find herself out of pocket because of the system. Three years ago she and her ex-husband remortgaged their home through Bradford & Bingley and his name appeared first on the policy. At the end of last year she transferred the account into her name only. Shortly afterwards, borrowers who had taken out their loan before April 1999 were told they would receive shares if the company floated on the stock market, but Simmons found herself ineligible because during the qualifying period her ex-husband was the official account holder. "As far as I am aware we were not asked which name we wished to appear first," she says. "Now neither of us will receive anything." Bradford & Bingley points to its terms and conditions which do explain (at the end of the eighth section) that the first name in a joint account is the nominal account holder with sole right to vote. Women beware - always read the small print. An ink cartridge is not just an ink cartridge David Godfrey of Twickenham wants to know how retailers can justify charging £26 for a 28ml ink cartridge used in his computer printer. "This works out at just under £1,080 per litre of ink," he rages. "What's so special about it?" More than the layman could ever fathom, according to a spokesman for the Dixons group which sells large numbers of such cartridges. "Over the past five years printers have dropped in price and part of their hi-tech facilities have been transferred to the cartridges," he says. So those bland plastic refills might contain their own in-built printer head, fade-proof ink, and a micro-chip or two. Really posh ones can deliver ink droplets of four million millionth of a litre to print fine quality photographs. They can't yet brew your early morning cuppa, alas, but doubtless that will come. webTitle: Brutal truth behind the headlines

fields.headline: Brutal truth behind the headlines
fields.standfirst:
The tabloid press is incapable of dealing with a child's murder in a sensible and sensitive manner
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: For the third summer in a row the arrival of the holidays has been accompanied by gruelling, grisly coverage in all media of a child's murder, probably by a paedophile.
fields.body:
For the third summer in a row the arrival of the holidays has been accompanied by gruelling, grisly coverage in all media of a child's murder, probably by a paedophile.

Parents are understandably very concerned by the story. Kids are charging about enjoying the sunshine (with any luck) and looking forward to weeks of freedom from teachers. How could I live with myself, parents wonder, if something happened? This is what is so hideous for a parent of a murdered child - whatever the circumstances, the parent is bound to think of some way in which they could have prevented it happening and, therefore, is bound to be plagued with guilt, in most cases for the rest of their lives.

The trouble with all this is that, although it is a hideous prospect, it is utterly absurd for parents to be worrying about the safety of their children. They are at no greater danger than they have ever been in recent times.

The only reason parents are worrying so much is because the tabloids, followed sheepishly by the broadcast media, have realised that playing on parents' fears sells newspapers. For the unforgivably hypocritical Daily Mail, which makes itself out to be concerned about families and piously against crime, this story is a cynical method for increasing circulation. The reality of child murder is as follows: about 80 children are murdered every year. Of these, an average of just seven are killed by someone with whom they were not previously acquainted. The vast majority of victims are killed by their parents and of these, the majority have a low income.

If the Daily Mail really wanted to draw attention to an important social problem they would focus on this latter fact: that one quarter of children are still being raised in low-income homes as a result of the economic policies of Mrs Thatcher, whom the Mail so vigorously supported.

But that is hardly likely to be their focus. Instead, they devote huge space and energy to turning a real life horror story into an episode of Cracker or Inspector Morse. The awful truth is that there is a huge market for these ghastly stories because we, including me and including you, are completely gripped by the unfolding saga. We do want to hear the perverse detail that Sarah was found naked, that the murderer seems to have customised his van for committing the crime and so on. We do pay attention as the narrative is unpacked for us.

It begins with the child going missing. Then the parents are wheeled out to express their concern. Small clues emerge... Sarah last seen by sibling... man with white van seen nearby... police widening search, and so on. It becomes obvious that the child is dead and we find ourselves, mostly unconsciously, identifying with what it would be like to be sexually abused and murdered as a child, what it would be like to be living with the likelihood that this has happened to our child. And we do find this entertaining, just as we enjoy horror movies or crime fiction.

But most worrying of all, I believe we also must be identifying with what it would be like to be the perpetrator of this crime, if nothing else, at the level of being the man who is calling all the shots, leading the police a merry dance. The awful truth is that we are fascinated and excited by these crimes. That is the only possible explanation for the massive and unrelenting success of the innumerable TV dramas which use these plotlines.

But the fact that humans are base and vile is no excuse for the annual charade of the child murder that is now played out every summer. We have to be protected from ourselves and it is most nauseating of all to see the Mail and its brethren both pretending to follow these stories in the public interest and actually using them to sustain sales.

One solution would be for them to exercise restraint - but that is like expecting a paedophile to stop his perversions voluntarily. Paul Dacre (the Mail's sanctimonious editor) and Lynda Lee Potter must get their daily fix of nastiness dressed up as public interest.

The only hope is for government to control this more directly through the press regulator and by stopping the police from mounting an obscene annual show.

There is absolutely no need to give so much detail: why do we have to be told whether the victim was fully clothed or not? Why are we informed that the parents were not allowed to see the body (implying it had been mutilated)?

If the Mail were even slightly sincere in its claims of public interest, it would focus on the real dangers for children: of asthma, caused by 20 years of Mail-backed Tory failure to curb car use; of grossly unhealthy diets, leading to overweight children who will become heart attack victims in adulthood; above all, of having parents on a low income.

But the Mail cares nothing about these things. Far better to flog lots of copies by titillating us and terrifying parents with the story of the sexual murder of a small child.

Oliver James is a clinical psychologist and author of Britain on the Couch, published by Arrow.

webTitle: First of the pinch hitters?

fields.headline: First of the pinch hitters?
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: I've heard that Krishnamachari Srikkanth of India was the first pinch hitter in one-day internationals. What was his highest score? asks Kannan Tirupachanur
fields.body:
I've heard that Krishnamachari Srikkanth of India was the first pinch hitter in one-day internationals. What was his highest score? asks Kannan Tirupachanur

Actually Srikkanth was almost a pinch hitter in Test cricket, as well as one-day internationals. He was an uninhibited opener who went for his shots right from the start. Ironically he made his debut in one of the dreariest of Test series - against England in 1981-82. India won the first Test (Srikkanth 0 and 13) and then Sunil Gavaskar and Keith Fletcher, the rival captains, seemed content to play out five boring draws on placid pitches. Srikkanth finished up with 2062 runs in 43 Tests, at an average of just under 30. He cracked two entertaining centuries: 116 v Australia at Sydney in 1985-86, when he reached his hundred from 97 balls and hit legspinner Bob Holland for 22 in an over, and 123 v Pakistan at Madras in 1986-87. That time he reached 50 in 86 balls, but needed only 32 more to reach 100. He captained India in four Tests in 1989-90, and last played for them in 1991-92.

In one-day internationals - a form of the game which might have been invented for him - Srikkanth scored 4092 runs in 146 matches, and again averaged 29. He hit four hundreds, three in India and one in Sharjah. His highest one-day score was 123, like his Test-best, and came against Pakistan at Calcutta in 1986-87. He was top-scorer, with 38, in the 1983 World Cup final, when India pulled off a surprise victory over West Indies, the holders and overwhelming favourites.

Whether Srikkanth was a pinch hitter (a term borrowed from baseball) is debatable - he was just playing his normal game. The first time the term was widely used was during the 1996 World Cup, when Sri Lanka promoted Sanath Jayasuriya and Romesh Kaluwitharana from the middle order to take advantage of the regulation restricting the number of outfielders in the first 15 overs. The tactic was tried during the 1992 World Cup as well - Ian Botham had a mixed time of it for England, but Mark Greatbatch had more success for New Zealand.

Who wrote the song that was the theme tune for the BBC's cricket programmes? asks Hywel ap Rees

That tune was "Soul Limbo", which was written and recorded in the early 1960s by Booker T Jones, Steve Cropper, Donald "Duck" Dunn and Al Jackson junior, who were collectively known as Booker T and the MGs (the MG bit stood for "Memphis Group"). I tracked down a copy of the group's Greatest Hits CD on www.amazon.co.uk for £6.99, if you're interested.

Who is the youngest player to score a Test century? asks Tilak Malaviya

It's Mushtaq Mohammad, who was only 17 years 82 days old when he made 101 for Pakistan v India at New Delhi in 1960-61. India's Sachin Tendulkar nearly beat him, but he was 30 days older than Mushtaq when he reached three figures for the first time in a Test, with 119 not out against England at Old Trafford in 1990.

Which England batsman had his arm broken during the 1984 Old Trafford Test? asks David Ides

It was Paul Terry, the Hampshire batsman (and fine fielder), who made his debut in the third Test against West Indies that year, at Headingley. Although he made only 8 and 1, he retained his place for the Old Trafford Test - but probably wished he hadn't when a ball from Winston Davis fractured his left arm. He retired hurt with 7, but returned later to help Allan Lamb reach his century. Terry, who was born in West Germany in 1959, never won another Test cap, but he played on for Hampshire until 1996, when he retired and moved to Western Australia. He finished with 16,427 first-class runs at an average of 36.66, with 38 hundreds, and over 8500 runs in domestic one-day cricket.

Who was the first player of Asian or West Indian descent to play Test cricket for England? asks Vidura Gunapala

It was KS Ranjitsinhji, the stylish Indian-born batsman who played for Sussex around the turn of the last century. "Ranji", who later became the Jam Saheb (prince) of Nawanagar, made his Test debut for England against Australia at Old Trafford in 1896, and scored 62 and 154 not out. He followed that up with 175 in his first Test in Australia, at Sydney in 1897-98. In all he scored 989 runs (44.95) in 15 Tests. In first-class cricket he scored 24,692 runs at the tremendous average of 56.37, passing 3000 in 1899 and again in 1900. India's Ranji Trophy is named after him, although he never actually played first-class cricket in India.

Pelham Warner, England's captain in Australia in 1903-04, was born in Trinidad, but the first black West Indian-born player to represent England was Roland Butcher, who made his Test debut against West Indies on his native Barbados in 1980-81.

What is the highest team score recorded in a one-day international, and what's Australia's highest? asks Paula Freeman

The highest total in an official one-day international is Sri Lanka's 398 for 5 against Kenya at Kandy during the 1996 World Cup. Aravinda de Silva hit 145, Asanka Gurusinha 84 and Arjuna Ranatunga 75 not out. Martin Suji (9-0-85-1) was the chief sufferer among the bowlers. Australia's highest was set only last winter - 349 for 6 v New Zealand at Christchurch on Feb 26. Their previous record was 337 for 7, set 22 days previously against Pakistan at Sydney.

Someone called E Crush dismissed Don Bradman when Kent played the Australians in 1948. Can you tell me anything about him? asks Bruce Reid

Edmund "Eddie" Crush was born in Crabble, near Dover, on April 25, 1917. He bowled quickish offbreaks, almost at medium-pace, and played 45 matches as an amateur for Kent between 1946 and 1949. In all he took 83 wickets, at an average of 38.10. In the match against Hampshire at Canterbury in 1948 he made his highest score (78) and returned his best bowling figures (6 for 50). In that game against the Australians Crush had Bradman caught off a skyer by Bryan Valentine at mid-off for 65. The Australians - who went through the tour unbeaten and are now remembered as "The Invincibles" - made 361, then bowled Kent out for 51 and 124 to win by an innings and 186 runs.

Are there any proposals to publish another "Wisden Anthology", on the lines of those edited by the late Benny Green which covered the periods 1864 to 1982? asks Peter Collier

There are no immediate plans, but our colleagues at John Wisden & Co., who sometimes license out the Wisden name for suitable projects, say they are hoping to interest a publisher in the idea at some time in the future.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous question-and-answer session, which has details of the forthcoming memorial match for Malcolm Marshall, click here

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

webTitle: Caine on hand for last orders

fields.headline: Caine on hand for last orders
fields.trailText: Michael Caine has signed on to play the central role in an adaptation of Graham Swift's novel Last Orders
fields.body:
Michael Caine has signed on to play the central role in an adaptation of Graham Swift's novel Last Orders. The story follows a group of ageing companions as they journey from London to the coast in order to scatter the ashes of a dead friend. Caine will play the part of the dead man - butcher Jack Dodd - though fans will be relieved to note that the role consists of more than skulking silently inside an ornamental urn. The living, hydrated Dodd features in the film's lengthy flashback sections.

Last Orders is budgeted at £8m and will be directed by Australian film-maker Fred Schepisi. Co-starring alongside Caine are Tom Courtenay, Bob Hoskins, David Hemmings and Helen Mirren. The source novel won the Booker Prize in 1996 but ran into controversy when it was later alleged that Swift had heavily based his material on the 1929 William Faulkner tale, As I Lay Dying.

Since scooping an Oscar earlier this year, Caine has been working to a flat-out schedule. April and May found him in the east end working on a British crime caper, Shiner, while he is currently in the US shooting Miss Congeniality opposite Sandra Bullock. Last Orders is set to roll before the cameras on October 16.

April and May found him in the east end working on a British crime caper, Shiner, while he is currently in the US shooting Miss Congeniality opposite Sandra Bullock. Last Orders is set to roll before the cameras on October 16.

webTitle: The Dickens of a house

fields.headline: The Dickens of a house
fields.trailText: Miss Havisham's house revamped and refurbished could hardly be Miss Havisham's house any more.
fields.body:
A few days ago the Guardian ran a brief report from an agency under the headline: "Miss Havisham's house restored". The house at Rochester, Kent, that inspired Dickens's Great Expectations, the story explained, had reopened to the public after a six-year revamp.

Some dislocation here, surely: Miss Havisham's house revamped and refurbished could hardly be Miss Havisham's house any more. The house, as Pip first sees it from the street, is of old brick, and dismal; some of the windows are barred and some bricked up. But that is nothing to what he finds when he ventures inside. All is yellow and faded and scattered with crumbling relics of an abandoned wedding. The clocks are all stopped at 20 to nine. In the midst of all this is Miss Havisham: a bride in her bridal dress, now shrunk to the skin and bone - like a waxwork, it seems to Pip; like a skeleton.

Rochester is full of Charles Dickens. Its amiable, erratic high street is punctuated by plaques. Eastgate House, which houses a Dickens centre, is the Westgate House of Pickwick Papers and the Nun's House in Edwin Drood. Close by are the premises "of a peppercorny and farinaceous character" where Pip's Uncle Pumblechook plied his trade as cornchandler and seedsman. Here too is Fagin's cafe, and Ye Olde Curiositie restaurant, the Two Cities restaurant and takeaway, and Mr Tope's bistro (he is the verger in Edwin Drood). There is even Haversham's Quality Nearly New and Country Hardwares, though that may be just coincidence.

Turn into Crow Lane, past the Baptist church and the job centre, and you come to Miss Havisham's House (Satis House in the novel). Except that it isn't "Miss Havisham's House". It presents itself, now as when Dickens first saw it, as Restoration House, built in the 1580s, and so named because Charles II stayed there on the night of May 28 1660 on his way from Dover to London.

As the Guardian said, it has now emerged from a process of loving refurbishment, to reflect an age long before Dickens. Upstairs is what they still call Miss Havisham's room, but there is little now of her derelict presence. The entertainer and accomplice of Emu, Rod Hull, bought this house 13 years ago to save it from being converted to offices and having its garden reduced to a carpark. In those days, Miss Havisham's room was indeed Miss Havisham's room, all clutter and cob webs, complete with a wedding cake and an effigy of the lady in her faded, tragic finery. No room for such vulgarities now: instead you come to admire the 17th century panelling and the mid-18th century chandelier and the Reynolds. There isn't a cobweb in sight.

To say that this house "inspired Great Expectations" is to stretch a point till it snaps. But no doubt its solemn aspect helped to plant Miss Havisham's image in Dickens's mind. Her fate is briefly explained: "The marriage day was fixed, the wedding dresses were bought, the wedding-tour was planned out, the wedding guests were invited. The day came, but not the bridegroom." Miss Havisham is a grotesque, but like others among Dickens's most haunting grotesques only a step or two away from reality. As a child, I used to visit a small town in Sussex where the grocer's shop was run by a man whose daughter had met the same fate: the day came, but not the bridegroom. And now she sat day after day at an upstairs windows, shrieking and screaming abuse at her father's customers. No doubt her clocks too had stopped at 20 to nine. Like Pip's, my eyes were opened to a world previously unsuspected, where love and the thwarting of love could destroy a mind and shut out the sun for ever.

"I had stopped to look at the house as I passed," Pip remembers, "and its seared, red-bricked walls, blocked windows and strong green ivy clasping even the stacks of chimneys with its twigs and tendons, as if with sinewy arms, had made up a rich attractive mystery, of which I was the hero." Nine years after he finished Great Expectations, Dickens, who had walked into Rochester from his home at Gad's Hill, was seen one June day with his hands on the railings, gazing at this house, almost as if it had further mysteries waiting to be revealed.

Two days later, he wrote in his unfinished mystery Edwin Drood a famous evocation of Rochester: "A brilliant morning shines on the old city. Its antiquities and ruins are surpassingly beautiful.... the cold stone tombs of centuries grow warm; and flecks of brightness dart into the sternest marble corners of the building, fluttering there like wings." These were almost the last words he wrote. At dinner time that night he suffered a stroke. He died at ten to six the next evening.

 Restoration House is open Thursdays and Fridays only from July to September 29.

webTitle: Poets cook up bill of fare worse than verse

fields.headline: Poets cook up bill of fare worse than verse
fields.trailText: Like many poets, WH Auden was famously unfussy about hygiene but a stickler for good manners. So he was always careful to scrape the fungae off before offering food to guests in his garret.
fields.body:
Like many poets, WH Auden was famously unfussy about hygiene but a stickler for good manners. So he was always careful to scrape the fungae off before offering food to guests in his garret.

This may explain why the Poetry Society is unusually coy about its latest initiative, a series of literary soirées at which some of the country's best poets will not only entertain a select gathering of dinner guests with their wit and verse, but cook for them, too.

Three of the five poets shortlisted for the Forward Prize, Britain's most prestigious and lucrative poetry award, have agreed to skivvy in the kitchen, creating three courses for the bargain price of £17.50 a head, including aperitif. Somehow it is hard to imagine Martin Amis donning a pinny so readily to cater for hoi polloi.

Rubber chicken will not be on the menu either, according to Jessica York, who runs the Poetry Cafe in Soho, central London. Poets may be if anything poorer than they were in Auden's day, but, she claims, at least they've learned to cook. "We have some real wizards. I think people will be pleasantly surprised."

Despite using a cat as a condiment in his poem, Roadkill, Matthew Sweeney has a formidable reputation for cordon bleu on the north London dinner party circuit, and Sarah Maguire's taste for all things ethnic is reflected in her choice of a Lebanese banquet.

The provenance of the cooking of fellow Forward nominee, Michael Donaghy, is another matter, however. His partner, Maddy, was shocked, not to say appalled, to hear yesterday that he would be cooking a Mexican meal for 20 in September to kick off the Dinner With... series. "What? Well, he'll have to do it himself, I'm not being landed with it. I going to be out of the country."

Last night Donaghy, whose latest poetry collection, entitled Conjure, has been hugely praised, was beating a hasty retreat, blaming the bottle, that traditional scourge of a many a good poet. "Oh my God, what have I done? I need to go on an assertiveness course to learn to say no. I was drunk when I agreed to do it, and when I have drink in me I'll agree to do anything. I couldn't cook the Mexican equivalent of cheese on toast. I've just come back from Mexico, and I now hate Mexican food. I even think I might have got hepatitis there."

Whatever is known about American-born Donaghy's culinary skills beyond boil-in-a-bag, his talents as a dinner guest, raconteur and entertainer are not in question. He is also a jazz and Irish traditional musician of note. "I do anything, I mean anything, but I won't cook," he said.

There are worries, too, about Scott Verner, another of the six poets taking part, who was a chef before becoming editor the Poetry London magazine. He is dallying between a Japanese and Cajun dish.

Sweeney, whose new poetry collection is called, appropriately, The Smell Of Fish, said poetry and cooking were similar in many ways. "Both call for precision, control and a little sprinkling of wit. And I promise you, no cats, though Roadkill is a real recipe."

Roadkill

Scrape the cat off the road
take it home and fillet out the flesh
throw it in the marinade
where the deer you wrecked your bumper on
a week before Xmas, sits
in chunks, alongside slivers of fox,
a boned, de-spined hedgehog,
the legs and breasts of a slow hare -
all in a bath of red wine
with onion slices and garlic,
and an ounce of juniper berries.
That cat was the last ingredient
you didn't know you needed
and had better keep secret.
After a day, strain the marinade
and cook the meat all morning
in the wine and blood.
Serve in bowls, with bread.

Matthew Sweeney
from A Smell Of Fish (Cape £8)
